{{technical|date=August 2016}}
'''293T''' (or HEK293T) is a human cell line, derived from the [[HEK 293]] cell line, that expresses a mutant version of the [[SV40 large T antigen]]. It is very commonly used in biology for protein expression and production of recombinant [[retroviruses]].
== Origin == 293T was created in Michele Calos's lab at Stanford by [[transfection#Stable and transient transfection|stable transfection]] of the HEK 293 cell line with a plasmid encoding a temperature-sensitive mutant of the SV40 large T antigen; it was originally referred to as 293/''tsA1609neo''.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=DuBridge RB, Tang P, Hsia HC, Leong PM, Miller JH, Calos MP |title=Analysis of mutation in human cells by using an Epstein-Barr virus shuttle system |journal=Mol. Cell. Biol. |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=379–387 |date=Jan 1987 |pmid=3031469 |pmc=365079 |doi=10.1128/MCB.7.1.379 }}</ref> The first reference to the cell line as "293T" may be its use to create the [[BOSC23]] packaging cell line for producing retroviral particles.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Pear WS, Nolan GP, Scott ML, Baltimore D |title=Production of high-titer helper-free retroviruses by transient transfection |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA |volume=90 |issue=18 |pages=8392–8396 |date=15 Sep 1993 |pmid=7690960 |pmc=47362 |doi=10.1073/pnas.90.18.8392}}</ref>
== Characteristics == The transfection used to create 293T (involving plasmid pRSV-1609) conferred [[neomycin]]/[[G418]] resistance and expression of the tsA1609 allele of SV40 large T antigen; this allele is fully active at 33 °C (its [[permissive temperature]]), has substantial function at 37 °C, and is inactive at 40 °C.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rio DC, Clark SG, Tjian R |title=A mammalian host-vector system that regulates expression and amplification of transfected genes by temperature induction |journal=Science |volume=227 |issue=4682 |pages=23–28 |date=4 Jan 1985 |pmid=2981116 |doi=10.1126/science.2981116 }}</ref> 293T is very efficiently transfectable with DNA (like its parent HEK 293). Due to the expression of SV40 large T antigen, transfected plasmid DNAs that carry the SV40 [[origin of replication]] can replicate in 293T and will transiently maintain a high copy number; this can greatly increase the amount of recombinant protein or retrovirus that can be produced from the cells.
== Genome == The full genome sequences of three different isolates of 293T have been determined. They are quite similar to each other but show detectable divergence from the parental HEK 293 cell line.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lin YC, Boone M, Meuris L, Lemmens I, Van Roy N, Soete A, Reumers J, Moisse M, Plaisance S, Drmanac R, Chen J, Speleman F, Lambrechts D, Van de Peer Y, Tavernier J, Callewaert N |title=Genome dynamics of the human embryonic kidney 293 lineage in response to cell biology manipulations |journal=Nat. Commun. |volume=5 |at=4767 |date=3 Sep 2014 |pmid=25182477 |pmc=4166678 |doi=10.1038/ncomms5767 }}</ref>

'''Abu Muhammad Abd Allah bin Muhammad bin Qasim bin Hilal bin Yazid bin 'Imran al-'Absi al-Qaysi''' was an early Muslim jurist and theologian.<ref>[[Al-Humaydī]], ''Jadhwat al-Muqtabis'', vol. 2, entry #418.</ref>
==Life== Having been born in [[Islamic Spain]], Ibn Qasim moved to [[Iraq]] for a time, studying directly under [[Dawud al-Zahiri]]. He ended up leaving the [[Maliki]]te rite of Muslim [[Fiqh|jurisprudence]] for the [[Zahiri]]te branch, and was considered by [[Christopher Melchert]] to be the first Zahirite in the region.<ref>''The Islamic school of law - evolution, devolution, and progress'', pg. 118. Eds. Rudolph Peters and Frank E. Vogel. [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]]: [[Harvard Law School]], 2005.</ref> Ibn Qasim copied his teacher's books by hand and was responsible for spreading them throughout [[Al-Andalus]].
Ibn Qasim died in the year 272 on the [[Islamic calendar]], corresponding to 885 or 886 on the [[Gregorian calendar]].<ref name=samir541>Samir Kaddouri, "Refutations of Ibn Hazm by Maliki Authors from al-Andalus and North Africa." Taken from ''Ibn Hazm of Cordoba: The Life and Works of a Controversial Thinker'', pg. 541. Eds. [[Camilla Adang]], [[Maribel Fierro]] and [[Sabine Schmidtke]]. [[Leiden]]: [[Brill Publishers]], 2013. {{ISBN|9789004243101}}</ref>
He was listed by later Zahirite jurist [[Ibn Hazm]] as having been, along with [[Ruwaym]], [[Ibn al-Mughallis]] and [[Mundhir bin Sa'īd al-Ballūṭī]], one of the primary proponents of the Zahirite [[Madhhab|school]] of [[Islamic law]].<ref name=samir541/> Ibn Hazm, who was also an early champion of the school, was essentially reviving Ibn Qasim's efforts;<ref>S. M. Imamuddin, ''Muslim Spain 711-1492 A.D.: A Sociological Study'' pg. 156. [[Leiden]]: [[Brill Publishers]], 1981.</ref> earlier Zahirites such as Balluti kept their views to themselves.<ref>Mohammad Sharif Khan and Mohammad Anwar Saleem, ''Muslim Philosophy And Philosophers'', pg. 35. [[New Delhi]]: Ashish Publishing House, 1994.</ref><ref>[[Bilal Orfali]], "In the Shadow of Arabic: The Centrality of Language to Arab Culture." Pg. 34. [[Brill Publishers]], 2011. Print.</ref><ref>[[William Montgomery Watt]] and Pierre Cachi, "History of Islamic Spain," pg. 66. [[Edinburgh University Press]].</ref>

{{Good article}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Adam (''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'')}} {{Infobox Buffyverse character |name = Adam |image = Adam(buffy).jpg |imagesize = <!-- default 270 --> |caption = George Hertzberg portrayed Adam mindful both of "boyish innocence" and a programmed directive to kill. |alt = |first = "[[The I in Team]]" (2000) |last = "[[Lessons (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Lessons]]" (2002) |creator = [[Joss Whedon]] |portrayer = [[George Hertzberg]] |groups = [[Initiative (Buffyverse)|Initiative]] |role = "[[Cyborg|Bio-mechanical]] [[demon]]oid" |abilities = [[Superhuman strength]], stamina, and durability. Skewer, collapsible [[minigun]] and [[grenade launcher]] housed within arms. [[Technopathy|Cybernetic abilities]]. }}
'''Adam''' is a [[fictional character]] in the [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (season 4)|fourth season]] of the television series ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]''. Portrayed by [[George Hertzberg]], he is a monster created from a man and the collected parts of demons, vampires, and technology: the product of a perverse experiment carried out by military scientists. The series' main character, [[Buffy Summers]], encounters and ultimately defeats him in the fourth season. Adam is the creation of Dr. [[Maggie Walsh]] ([[Lindsay Crouse]]), the head of a military-like organization called [[The Initiative (Buffy the Vampire Slayer organization)|The Initiative]] that studies how to alter the harmful behavior inherent to demons. Adam and the Initiative are the fourth season's primary antagonists, or [[Big Bad]].
The premise of the series is that Buffy ([[Sarah Michelle Gellar]]) is a [[Slayer (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Slayer]], endowed with superhuman strength to fight vampires and evil creatures in the fictional town of [[Sunnydale]]. In the fourth season, Buffy begins attending college, where she discovers that her psychology professor, Walsh, is a scientist for the Initiative. Adam is Dr. Walsh's horrible masterpiece, an allusion to [[Frankenstein's monster]], whose first conscious act is killing his creator. Adam's search for understanding himself and his true nature, combined for his penchant for chaos, leads him to orchestrate a massacre between demons and humans, after which he will be able use body parts left over from the melee to create an army of monsters to set loose on Sunnydale. Buffy's effectiveness as a Slayer is increased because her close friends and family, called the [[Scooby Gang (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Scooby Gang]], assist her in her battles. By the end of season four the members of the group have become estranged and must come back together in order to defeat the apparently invincible Adam.
[[Buffy studies]] scholars have critically examined the character of Adam, noting that he is a clear reference to [[Frankenstein's monster]]. Throughout the action of the novel, the monster constantly asks what he is and why he was created, much like Adam. Whedon wanted Adam to be inquisitive and introspective, directing George Hertzberg to "find the stillness" in the character. The presence of Adam also serves to question tradition and authority, specifically institutional authority, which is a repeated theme on the show. Adam has a "design flaw": Adam finds Dr. Walsh unnecessary (his existence supplemented with technology), and as such kills her{{em dash}}a clear example of rejecting authority. Critical reception to Adam has largely ranged from mixed to negative. Some commentators felt his subplot was confusing and unconvincing. Others enjoyed the concept and praised the make-up and special effects used to create the character.
==Character arc==
===Television appearances=== Adam makes his first appearance on the thirteenth episode of season four, "[[The I in Team]]". The first twelve episodes of the season establish the overarching themes, with increasing focus on the mysterious activities of the Initiative. Buffy and Willow begin attending college, an experience which overwhelms Buffy immediately as she finds herself far outside her comfort zone.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 196–208</ref><ref>Stafford, pp. 215–220</ref> In the season premiere, Buffy and Willow begin attending a challenging psychology class taught by Dr. [[Maggie Walsh]] ([[Lindsay Crouse]]). She also meets Dr. Walsh's teaching assistant [[Riley Finn]] ([[Marc Blucas]]) and they become attracted to each other. Riley is in charge of a military commando organization that hunts vampires and demons, and captures them for research. It is not revealed to audiences that Dr. Walsh is the head of the research branch of Riley's military organization, called the Initiative, until the [[The Initiative (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|seventh episode]].<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 196–212</ref><ref>Stafford, pp. 215–231</ref>
The Initiative's goals are gradually made clearer. A recurring character since the second season is [[Spike (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Spike]] ([[James Marsters]]), a mercenary vampire who has fought both against and with Buffy in the past, depending on what suits his interests. Recently wanting to kill Buffy, Spike is captured by the Initiative before he can get to her and implanted with a chip in his brain that causes intense pain if he tries to attack humans to feed on them, or even to fight them.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 212–214</ref><ref>Stafford, pp. 222–225</ref> Buffy begins enthusiastically training with the Initiative, spending more time with Riley, and trying to impress Dr. Walsh. At different times, Willow, Xander, and Giles caution Buffy that she does not know the Initiative's true motives and there are questions about their mission that are unanswered. Buffy begins asking questions during "[[The I in Team]]". After being sent after a Polgara demon, a being with a skewer in its arm, she wants to know why the demon must be captured alive and unharmed as she is used to killing demons. Her questions at first confound Dr. Walsh—who answers to no one—then cement Dr. Walsh's decision to remove Buffy from the Initiative. After a botched attempt to kill Buffy, Dr. Walsh consoles herself by going into laboratory room 314 and speaking to her pet project, Adam who is laying on a table, apparently unconscious. Adam rises and impales Dr. Walsh with the skewer in his arm—the one taken off the Polgara demon. His first word is "Mommy", which he says as Dr. Walsh falls to the floor, dead.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 227–230</ref><ref name="s231">Stafford, pp. 231–232</ref>
Riley, meanwhile, learns of Dr. Walsh's death and his comrades [[Forrest Gates|Forrest]] ([[Leonard Roberts]]) and [[Graham Miller (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Graham]] ([[Bailey Chase]]) suspect Buffy to be her murderer. Extremely agitated and showing signs of drug withdrawal, he follows Buffy and demands to know the truth in "[[Goodbye Iowa]]". None of them are aware of Adam until he re-emerges in the underground laboratories of the Initiative, killing Dr. Walsh's assistant and another soldier. He tells Riley that he knows Dr. Walsh created them both, that she gave Riley chemicals to strengthen him, which makes them brothers. When Riley refuses to acknowledge their bond, Adam skewers Riley, and knocks Buffy across the room while Forrest and Graham are trying to enter the locked door. Adam leaves and the Initiative are tasked with hunting him down and killing him.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 231–232</ref><ref>Richardson and Rabb, p. 67</ref> When one of Sunnydale's residents, [[Jonathan Levinson]] ([[Danny Strong]]), casts a spell making him the center of everyone's attention in "[[Superstar (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Superstar]]", Adam is the only character in town who realizes it is an illusion. He explains his insight by saying he is "aware". His uniqueness has set him apart.<ref>Stevenson, pp. 27–28</ref> Adam is interested in how the illusion will play out, however, and watches it unfold. During the illusion, Jonathan—temporarily a part of the Inititative—discovers Adam's only weakness: a uranium power core source which, effectively, will never allow him to die.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 237–238</ref>
Spike simultaneously discovers Adam to be communicating with the town's demon underworld, asking for favors through a charisma he has over them. Adam promises if Spike can drive apart Buffy and Riley and their friends, he will remove Spike's microchip.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 239–244</ref><ref name="s242">Stafford, pp. 239–242</ref> The plan to drive Buffy, Willow, Xander, and Giles apart works for a while; at their lowest, the four refuse to speak to each other, but each of them realizes in "[[Primeval (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Primeval]]" that they were manipulated by Spike and return, apologetic. They realize that Adam has been orchestrating the capture of the town's vampires and demons so he can release them in the Initiative; the Initiative's holding cells are becoming overcrowded and the soldiers spread very thin and overworked. The soldiers and demons will then proceed to kill each other. Adam then intends to use the resulting carnage to create an army of monsters much like himself.<ref name=holderprimeval>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 246–247</ref><ref name=staffordprimeval>Stafford, pp. 242–244</ref>
Buffy, Willow, Xander, and Giles realize they must work as one unit to defeat Adam. They are captured sneaking into the Initiative, but Adam trips the power, releasing all the demons and a fight breaks out all over the facility. Buffy, Willow, Xander, and Giles get themselves into a room adjacent to 314 as Willow starts to cast the spell to join them all temporarily. Riley distracts Adam's demonoid minions while Buffy confronts Adam. However, Adam, after modulating his arm to dispense a [[minigun]], is able to overpower her. Suddenly, the spell begins to work: to function as one unit, Willow becomes the spirit, Giles the mind, Xander the heart, and Buffy the hand, or strength of their ensemble. They work through Buffy to neutralize Adam, telling him "You could never hope to grasp the source of our power". Adam, alone but intrigued, shoots at them to no avail. Adam then shoots a missile, which is changed into doves, and his gun is reverted into his arm. They are able, through Buffy, to punch inside Adam's chest, remove his uranium core, destroying him.<ref name=richardson73>Richardson and Rabb, pp. 73–74</ref><ref>Stevenson, pp. 146–147</ref>
Adam's most significant influence following his death is in the next episode "[[Restless (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Restless]]", where the cost of defeating Adam is made apparent. ''Buffy'''s fourth season was a first in the series in that the Scoobies' defeat of the Big Bad did not occur in a two-part grand season finale. "Primeval" is not the last episode of the season. Joss Whedon felt so strongly about the importance of the four core characters that he dedicated the finale to exploring their development.<ref name=fourthoverview/> "Restless" opens with Buffy, Willow, Xander, and Giles arriving at Buffy's mother's house still brimming with the energy of the spell that bound them together in "Primeval". Each of them falls asleep quickly, however, and their dreams are a pastiche of enigmatic episodes that both reveal much about each character, but also foreshadow what will occur in seasons to come. Their dreams also mirror their roles in the spell they performed to kill Adam. The magic they used to defeat the influence of science creates an inverse crisis, violating the series' set of laws.<ref name=richardson73/> Both Riley and Adam, now only in human form, appear in Buffy's dream. They are wearing business suits, sitting together at a glass conference table as Buffy walks into the room, telling her they are naming things—as [[Adam]] did in the [[Garden of Eden]]—and making plans to take over the world. Buffy asks Adam what his name was before he was a monster, but he cannot tell her. Adam appears once more in the series as one of the faces of the [[First Evil]], the seventh season's Big Bad, in "[[Lessons (Buffy episode)|Lessons]]".<ref>Ruditis, pp. 167–170</ref>
===Graphic novel appearance=== According to the comic book series ''[[Haunted (Buffy comic)|Haunted]]'', Adam was once a human member of the Initiative tasked with protecting Professor Walsh. The ghost of [[Mayor (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Mayor Richard Wilkins]], however, took over the body of a vampire, which was then captured by the Initiative. Desperate to escape, the Mayor moved to the body of a dead demon and killed Adam. Having been one of her favorite agents, Professor Walsh vowed to bring him back to life and placed his body in her 314 Project.<ref name="comicbook">Espenson, ''passim''</ref> However, due to the [[Buffyverse canon|complex nature of the Buffyverse]], this chain of events may not, in fact, be canonical.<ref name=silverbullet>{{cite web|last=Naso|first=Markisan|title=Jeff Mariotte: Cursed|url=http://www.comicsbulletin.com/features/110791695145851.htm|publisher=Silver Bullet Comicbooks|accessdate=2 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807070912/http://www.silverbulletcomicbooks.com/features/110791695145851.htm|archivedate=7 August 2007}}</ref>
==Development==
===Creation and casting=== {{Quote box |quote = I think there is a boyish innocence to Adam, that coupled with his programming—which is basically to kill—makes him an evil demon being-man-machine-person. Is he evil or misunderstood? I don't think he's misunderstood. Can he be reprogrammed? I think it's possible, but if he was, I don't know how interesting that would be. |source = [[George Hertzberg]], outlining his character.<ref name=mag>{{cite journal|last=Stokes|first=Mike|title=Young Frankenstein|journal=[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer Magazine incorporating Angel Magazine|Buffy the Vampire Slayer Magazine]]|date=April 2001|issue=19|page=11}}</ref> | width = 30em | bgcolor= #CCCCFF | align = left | quoted = 1 }} Series writer [[David Fury]] cited graphic novel author [[Alan Moore]]'s ''[[Promethea]]''—a story combining science fiction, mysticism, and a female superhero—as inspiration for the storyline, and another nod to ''Frankenstein'' as its original title was ''Frankenstein; or, the Modern Prometheus''.<ref name=fourthoverview/><ref name=wilcox133/> In addition, series creator, Joss Whedon has long been interested in [[science fiction]]. He wrote the script for the film ''[[Alien Resurrection]]'' (1997), where an extraterrestrial creature is bred from a human and an alien in a laboratory, and went on to develop the [[space western]] television series ''[[Firefly (TV series)|Firefly]]''. ''Buffy'' uses both science and magic as narrative devices. According to author Andrew Aberdein, the series employs science in three ways: to demonstrate what contemporary science explains, to posit what science may be able to accomplish, and the dominance of supernatural forces over science. According to Aberdein, Adam, a "kinematically redundant, bio-mechanical demonoid", is the series' deepest exploration of scientific potential.<ref>South, pp. 79–90</ref> Series writer [[Doug Petrie]] states that Adam is the embodiment of the invasion of science in a world where magic is the most powerful force. The series relied on its own form of magic to explain Buffy's superpowers and other supernatural occurrences up to the fourth season. Adam is "what happens when people who believe in science use demons for military gain", according to Petrie. The result is that science "gets its ass kicked" by magic.<ref name=fourthoverview/>
''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' had been very successful in its first three seasons on television, but some of the characters left the series and storylines ended, creating a need for an entire shift in location and mission. Buffy and the core group of friends who fight with her graduate from high school, while the school itself was blown up in the third-season finale. The fourth season, therefore, presents viewers with Buffy, her best friends [[Willow Rosenberg|Willow]] ([[Alyson Hannigan]]), [[Xander Harris|Xander]] ([[Nicholas Brendon]]), and mentor [[Rupert Giles|Giles]] ([[Anthony Head]]) at a crossroads. Series creator [[Joss Whedon]] called it a "strange, sort of schizophrenic season" with a "weird incoherence", but also stated that the episodes in the fourth season were among the series' best. The writers set out to explore the characters' trials as they discover more about themselves following the defining years of high school. Although they had been a cohesive group of friends in the first three seasons, situations arise in the fourth to separate them. The writers focused on each of the four core characters individually throughout the season to increase the impact of their finally coming back together in the penultimate episode, "[[Primeval (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Primeval]]", when they merge their essences to form a super-Buffy in order to defeat Adam.<ref name="fourthoverview">{{cite video |people=[[Joss Whedon]] |date=2000 |title=Fourth Season Overview |medium= DVD |location=''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (season 4)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer Fourth Season]]'' |publisher=[[The WB Television Network]]|display-authors=etal}}</ref> [[File:George Hertzberg.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Actor [[George Hertzberg]] portrayed Adam in the series.]] [[George Hertzberg]], a [[University of Southern California]] graduate with experience in sitcoms and commercials, was chosen based on one of Adam's monologues he was given to read for the audition. Hertzberg counted luck and being in the right place at the right time in helping him get the role. Many recurring characters on ''Buffy'' start with one or two episodes, and when the writers or producers like their chemistry with other actors, they often make them a regular part of the cast. Hertzberg, however, understood at his reading that Adam was to be a major part of the fourth season.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 305–307</ref> Casting Director Amy Britt needed someone physically imposing for the part, with the {{convert|6|ft|4|in|m|adj=on}} Hertzberg fitting the bill. Britt stated, "this is a guy we're going to want eventually to have some affinity for. We can't just see him as an evil being. He is evil to the core [and] should scare us with his actions; but there's also innocence. Like the Frankenstein monster, you realize that they're only doing what they know. Or what they've been programmed to do. These aren't born creatures, these are creations."<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', p. 347</ref>
===Make-up=== When he auditioned, Hertzberg had no idea what Adam would look like in full costume and make-up. ''Buffy'' used a company named Optic Nerve to build the materials to make Hertzberg look like a demonoid. Almost immediately after Hertzberg got the part, Optic Nerve sketched and sculpted Adam's appearance. They had Hertzberg come in to have molds made for prosthetic parts to fit his head and face, arms, chest, and legs, then he was fitted for contact lenses. They also created separate hands and a chest to film for close-up shots. Adam has a [[Floppy disk|floppy disk drive]] mounted on his chest which, when used, had to be filmed without Hertzberg behind it. The entire construction of Adam's appearance took about two weeks.<ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 380–384</ref> Hertzberg's voice was also modified post-production. When he saw the full Adam prosthetic and costume, his biggest concern was being able to show nuanced facial expressions under so much latex. It took hours to get Hertzberg into his full costume, but even after it was fully applied on set, often he would have to wait even longer before he went in front of the cameras. He spoke of the need to stay focused during all the waiting while sweating underneath everything he wore for the part.<ref>Hertzberg, George. "[http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/buffy/interviews/nocturnal/interviews/george/index.shtml Interviews with George Hertzberg]", BBC Cult Buffy News (2005). Retrieved on 26 November 2011.</ref>
==Themes== [[File:Frankenstein's monster (Boris Karloff).jpg|thumb|200px|left|Adam serves as an allusion to [[Frankenstein's monster]].]] [[Buffy studies]] scholar Roz Kaveney states that estrangement from the self and others is the primary theme of the fourth season. To illustrate the absolute search for identity, the series writers created Adam, who is more truly alone than is anyone else.<ref>Kaveney, pp. 23–27</ref> He is a creature assembled from a man, vampires, demons, and cutting edge cybernetic technology. Adam was not the first re-animated corpse to be presented in the series. "[[Some Assembly Required (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Some Assembly Required]]" in the second season also had a Frankenstein monster-like creation and "[[Beauty and the Beasts]]" in the third includes references to ''[[Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde]]''; both touch on the misuse or abuse of science.<ref>Golden and Holder, pp. 83–85</ref><ref>Holder, ''et al.'', pp. 147–149</ref> Adam is a clear reference to [[Frankenstein's monster]], who in the novel ''[[Frankenstein]]'' (1818) tells his creator that he is the "Adam of your labours". [[Mary Shelley]] wrote the novel to highlight the problems progress, science, and industry create for humanity.<ref>Stevenson, p. 133</ref> Throughout the action, the monster constantly asks what he is and why he was created. Likewise, Adam escapes from 314 and makes his way out into the world, and much like Frankenstein's monster, he finds a little boy and asks the boy who and what he (Adam) is, then murders and dissects him. Adam is a curious character, seeking the truth and pontificating on what he has learned, even if he gained the knowledge through heartless violence. Whedon wanted Adam to be inquisitive and introspective, directing George Hertzberg to "find the stillness" in the character. Roz Kaveney notes that Hertzberg's "flawed but impressive performance" includes Adam's interesting idiosyncrasy of pausing each time he speaks, as if he is creating meaning with his own words and must consider the implications of what he is saying.<ref>Kaveney, pp. 77–78</ref> Author Nikki Stafford connects Adam's need to learn about the world around him to Frankenstein's monster: Adam must understand why other people are here and why he has emotions, a peculiarity of his creation as Dr. Walsh never encouraged others to question her.<ref>Stafford, pp. 232–233</ref> One Buffy studies writer draws comparisons between Dr. Walsh and [[Victor Frankenstein]], both of whom build monsters out of body parts "to compensate for human vulnerability".<ref>South, pp. 91–93</ref> The moral of Shelley's novel is that what science can accomplish is not necessarily what it should.<ref name=wilcox133>Wilcox and Lavery, pp. 133–142</ref><ref name=dial67>Dial-Driver, pp. 67–69</ref><ref>Wilcox, pp. 47–48</ref>
Questioning tradition and authority, specifically institutional authority, is a repeated theme on the show. Buffy was created to subvert the media trope of a young, petite girl who easily falls prey to a male monster. Resisting [[patriarchy]] is exhibited in Buffy's opposing the first season's [[Master (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Master]] ([[Mark Metcalf]]), the leader of a cult determined to cause the apocalypse, and again in the third season where exploring the issues of power and its abuse is a primary theme. Buffy opposes Sunnydale's secretly evil [[Mayor (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Mayor]] ([[Harry Groener]]), who is planning to transform into a giant demon and feed on the graduating class of Sunnydale High School. The military-industrial complex is at the heart of the authority question in season four, again drawing comparisons to ''Frankenstein''. Where Frankenstein's monster had no parental love, Adam has a "design flaw". Unlike Frankenstein's monster, who needs his creator to make him a mate, Adam supplants Dr. Walsh's existence with technology, finding her unnecessary and thus he kills her. Adam is the embodiment of the lack of moral guidance in pursuing scientific and technological advancement. He represents the cannibalistic nature of relentless and unchecked power: what that power wreaks comes back to devour its source.<ref>Stevenson, pp. 130–134</ref> ''Buffy'', however, subverts Shelley's novel in the way Adam is defeated. Both Frankenstein and the monster must suffer alone. ''Frankenstein'' itself is an inversion of the [[Romantic era]] ideal of a solitary hero who must endure struggles, by portraying the monster and its creator as isolated and miserable. Buffy, as the embodiment of the postfeminist [[Romantic hero]], further subverts this because the source of her success, according to Anita Rose, is that she fights with friends. Only then is she able to defeat Adam.<ref name=wilcox133/>
==Reception== Critical reception to Adam was largely mixed, with critics' opinions ranging from negative to positive. Nikki Stafford, in her book ''Bite Me!: The 10th Buffyversary Guide to the World of Buffy the Vampire Slayer'', was critical of Adam as well as the series doing several Frankenstein-inspired episodes so close together, noting that "Some Assembly Required" was aired "just two seasons" prior.<ref name="s231"/> Stafford called the entire ending sequence of "[[Primeval (Buffy the Vampire Slayer)|Primeval]]", which featured the reanimated corpses of several minor characters as well as the death of Adam, "stupid and disgusting" and wrote that the scene was a main reason she was "happily bidding adieu" to the plot involving Adam and the Initiative.<ref name="s242"/> Jenna Busch, in her book ''Joss Whedon: The Complete Companion'', called Adam "one of ''Buffy'''s least interesting Big Bads" and argued that his story-arc involving the Initiative was "rather unconvincing and somewhat off-putting".<ref>{{cite web|last=Busch|first=Jenna|title='Joss Whedon: The Complete Companion': Read an excerpt now|url=http://blog.zap2it.com/pop2it/2012/04/joss-whedon-the-complete-companion-read-an-excerpt-now.html|publisher=Zap2It|accessdate=2 June 2012|date=26 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120626053600/http://blog.zap2it.com/pop2it/2012/04/joss-whedon-the-complete-companion-read-an-excerpt-now.html|archivedate=26 June 2012|df=}}</ref>
Other reviews were more accepting of the character. Noel Murray from ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' was slightly more positive towards the concept of Adam. He wrote that he "love[d] the idea of Adam" but was having a hard time understanding the coherence of his application to the main plot. He cited inconsistencies in Adam's existence, noting, "Adam killed Professor Walsh weeks ago, and yet The Initiative is still fully operational, and no one seems overly bothered by the fact that one of their leaders was building a monster."<ref name=avclubyoko>{{cite web|last=Murray|first=Noel|title='The Yoko Factor' etc.|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/superstar-etc,32290/|publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]''|accessdate=2 June 2012|date=4 September 2009}}</ref> Murray, however, did conclude that the show's writers and producers "did a decent job of bringing [the plot involving Adam] to a conclusion".<ref name=avclubyoko/> Despite critiquing the larger plot, Murray was "always impressed with [Adam's] costume/make-up".<ref name=avclubsuper/> Furthermore, he was positively surprised that it "took [him] a minute to recognize" Adam's appearance in "Restless" sans makeup.<ref name=avclubsuper>{{cite web|last=Murray|first=Noel|title='Superstar' etc.|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/superstar-etc,32290/|publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]''|accessdate=2 June 2012|date=28 August 2009}}</ref>

{{short description|Australian cave diver}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Agnes Milowka | image = Agnes Milowka by J Axford.jpg|alt=Portrait of Agnes Milowka by James Axford at Melbourne Port Phillip Bay location, 2010. | image_size = 220px | caption = Portrait at Melbourne Port Phillip Bay, 2010 | birth_name = Agnieszka Milówka | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1981|12|23}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]]}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2011|02|27|1981|12|23}} | death_place = Tank Cave near [[Tantanoola, South Australia|Tantanoola]], [[South Australia]] | citizenship = Australian, Polish | death_cause = [[Drowning]] | occupation = [[technical diving|Technical diver]], [[Underwater photography|underwater photographer]], [[author]], [[Caving|cave explorer]], [[Marketing management|marketing manager]] | years_active = 2002–2011 | education = [[Caulfield Grammar School]] | alma_mater = [[Victoria University, Australia|Victoria University]], [[Flinders University]], [[University of Melbourne]]. | website = {{URL|www.agnesmilowka.com}} | signature = Line_Arrow_of_Agnes_Milowka.jpg | signature_alt = Cave diving directional marker with Agnes Milowka signature | signature_size = 120px }}
'''Agnes Milowka''' (23 December 1981 – 27 February 2011) was an [[Australia]]n [[technical diving|technical diver]], [[Underwater photography|underwater photographer]], [[author]], [[Maritime Archaeology|maritime archaeologist]] and [[Caving|cave explorer]].<ref name="Jill Heinerth">{{cite book | title=Cave diving in the modern world | first=Jill | last=Heinerth | year=2010 | publisher=Heinerth Productions Incorporated | location=Chapter 1, Cave diving in the modern world | isbn=0-9798789-4-2 | url=http://www.agnesmilowka.com/ag_media/docs/pdf/press/jillheinerth_cavedivingessentials_book.pdf}}</ref><ref name=CEGSA2010>{{cite journal|author=CEGSA |title=CEGSA Annual Report/2006 |newspaper=Cave Exploration Group South Australia |year=2010 |url=http://www.cegsa.org.au/NEWS/AR10.pdf |accessdate=7 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725100523/http://www.cegsa.org.au/NEWS/AR10.pdf |archivedate=25 July 2011 }}</ref><ref name="Diver Magazine">{{cite news | url=http://www.agnesmilowka.com/ag_media/docs/pdf/press/divermag_cockle_march2010_bishop.pdf | title=Beyond Toad Hall: Cave Diving Beneath Australia's Nullabor Desert | accessdate=18 March 2011 | first=Leigh | last=Bishop | date=February–March 2010 | publisher=Diver Magazine, Vol 35 Number 7}}</ref> She gained international recognition for penetrating deeper than previous explorers into cave systems across Australia and Florida, and as a public speaker and author on the subjects of diving and maritime archaeology.<ref name="BlueMagazine">{{cite news | url=http://www.agnesmilowka.com/ag_media/docs/pdf/press/blue_magazine_2010_i07_ag.pdf|title=Talking Tech: Watching the girls dive by|accessdate=12 September 2011 | first=Cath | last=Bates |date=Oct–Nov 2010|publisher=Blue Magazine, Issue 7|location=Egypt}}</ref> She died aged 29 while diving in a confined space.
==Early life and schooling== Born in [[Częstochowa]], [[Poland]], Milowka moved to [[Melbourne]] at an early age with her parents, attending [[Caulfield Grammar School]] from 1994 to 1999. At the school, she was a house captain, champion school rower and was a finalist in the statewide [[Victorian Certificate of Education|VCE]] achiever award.<ref> {{cite web | url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/police-struggle-to-reach-diver-lost-in-cave-maze-20110301-1bcta.html | title=Police struggle to reach diver lost in cave maze | accessdate=15 July 2011 | first=Megan | last=Levy | date=1 Mar 2011 | publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> She received her graduate degrees in [[Maritime Archaeology]] from [[Flinders University]] (2007), [[Bachelor of Business]], Marketing and Event Management from [[Victoria University, Australia|Victoria University]] (2008), [[Bachelor of Arts]], History and Australian Studies from [[University of Melbourne]] (2005), where she was a president of the Melbourne University Underwater Club (2003–2005).<ref name=MUUC2003>{{cite journal|author=MUUC |title=Annual General Meeting Minutes - 27 March 2003 |year=2003 |url=http://www.muuc.org.au/documents/2003-Mar-27.AGM_Minutes.kb.pdf |accessdate=18 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324054654/http://www.muuc.org.au/documents/2003-Mar-27.AGM_Minutes.kb.pdf |archivedate=24 March 2012 }}</ref> In the summer of 2007 she completed an internship in St. Augustine, Florida, with [[St. Augustine Light#Lighthouse Archaeological Maritime Program .28LAMP.29|LAMP]] (Lighthouse Archaeological Maritime Program), the research arm of the [[St. Augustine Light]]house & Museum, where she participated in the archaeological excavation of historic shipwreck sites.<ref name=LAMP2007>{{cite web|author=Flinders University Internships/Masters Classes|title=Lighthouse Archaeological Maritime Program (LAMP) USA/2007|publisher=Flinders University|year=2007|url=http://www.flinders.edu.au/ehl/archaeology/postgrad-programs/by-coursework/pg-in-maritime-arch/internships.cfm|accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> This work would introduce her to Florida diving, where she would go on to explore extensive cave systems. During her schooling, she participated as the researcher and diver in a series of qualitative underwater archeological research projects.<ref name=MAU2006>{{cite book | title=Port Albert Archaeological Project: Report of Investigations | first1=Brian | last1=Williams | first2=Karson | last2=Winslow | first3=Agnes | last3=Milowka | first4=Jason | last4=Raupp | year=2006 | location=Manuscripts on file at Maritime Archaeology Unit, Heritage Victoria, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.}}</ref><ref name="MAVA2006">{{cite book | title=A View from Above: Archaeological Site Inspections in East Gippsland, Victoria | first1=Jason Thomas | last1=Raupp | first2=Karson | last2=Winslow | first3=Agnes | last3=Milowka | first4=Brian | last4=Williams | year=2007 | publisher=Shannon Research Press | location=pp. 46-60, 2006 Program in Maritime Archaeology. | isbn=978-1-920736-26-2 | hdl=2328/14589}}</ref><ref name=AIMA2007>{{cite journal|author=AIMA |title=Wilsons Promontory Fieldwork February/March 2007 |url=http://www.aima.iinet.net.au/publications/newsletters/docs/NLv26n1y07.pdf |accessdate=7 April 2011 |journal=Newsletter of the Australasian Institute for Maritime Archaeology (AIMA) |date=March 2007 |issn=0814-1479 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218105223/http://www.aima.iinet.net.au/publications/newsletters/docs/NLv26n1y07.pdf |archivedate=18 February 2011 }}</ref><ref name=FUMAN2007>{{cite journal|author=FUMAN|title=Internship with Heritage Victoria’s Maritime Heritage Unit|journal=Flinders University Maritime Archaeology Newsletter|year=2007|url=http://www.uri.edu/artsci/his/mua/project_journals/FUMAN_2007.pdf|accessdate=7 April 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110426021628/http://www.uri.edu/artsci/his/mua/project_journals/FUMAN_2007.pdf|archivedate=26 April 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=FUFS2008>{{cite web|title=Flinders University 2008 Field School in Underwater Archaeology|publisher=The Museum of Underwater Archeology|date=4 February 2008|first=Mark|last=Staniforth|url=http://www.uri.edu/artsci/his/mua/project_journals/flinders08/flinders08_intro.shtml|accessdate=7 April 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110426021046/http://www.uri.edu/artsci/his/mua/project_journals/flinders08/flinders08_intro.shtml|archivedate=26 April 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Diving== In the effort coordinated by [[Victorian Speleological Association]] in 2009, she and James Arundale explored Elk River streamway cave system by an additional {{convert|1400|m}}, which has potential to become the longest continuous stream passage in Victoria, Australia.<ref name=CEGSA552>{{cite web|author=CEGSA News |title=Past Trips From General Meetings |publisher=Cave Exploration Group (South Australia) |url=http://www.cegsa.org.au/NEWS/V55n2.pdf |accessdate=15 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001070556/http://www.cegsa.org.au/NEWS/V55n2.pdf |archivedate=1 October 2011 }}</ref> In a 2009 expedition near [[Cocklebiddy, Western Australia|Cocklebiddy]], she reached the midpoint of [[Craig Challen]]’s 2008 line giving her the record for the longest cave dive in Australia for a female.<ref name=CCDH>{{cite web|first1=Tony|last1=Richardson|first2=Chris|last2=Brown|title=Cocklebiddy Cave Diving History|publisher=Cave Divers Association of Australia|url=http://www.cavedivers.com.au/sites/default/files/finder/history/Cocklebiddy%20Cave%20Diving%20History.pdf|accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> She worked as an underwater [[Grip (job)|grip]] in 2008 for a film by Discovery Channel Japan, "Water's Journey" by TV Asahi & Karst Productions. She was part of the National Geographic Nova TV Special expedition to [[Blue Hole]]s of the Bahamas, in December 2008, as an underwater grip,<ref name="NSSCDS37">{{cite news|url=http://nsscds.org/test/drupal/content/%E2%80%9Chi-warg-mug-hi%E2%80%9D| title=Hi Warg Mug Hi| accessdate=12 September 2011 |first=Brian| last=Kakuk| newspaper=Underwater Speleology, Volume 37 Number 4| date=Oct 2010| publisher=National Speleological Society Cave Diving Section}}</ref> followed by the expedition to look for similar [[sinkholes]] in Queensland, Australia in October 2009.<ref name=BlueHolesQueensland>{{cite web|author=Sydney Project Dive Team|title=Technically Speaking: Blue Holes Exploration Trip|publisher=Sydney Project|url=http://www.sydneyproject.com/stories/technically-speaking/32-technically-speaking-blue-holes-exploration-trip.html|accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref>
Milowka was a photographic assistant on the ''[[National Geographic Magazine]]'' expedition to Bahamas Caves, November–December 2009, resulting in a few of her photos being published by the [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] website.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/explorers/projects/blue-holes/ | title=Blue Holes Project | accessdate=16 December 2011 | first=Agnes | last=Milowka | date=20 Dec 2008 | publisher=[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.agnesmilowka.com/ag_media/special/nationalgeographic_aug10_wallpaper_agnesmilowka.JPG | title=Deep Dark Secret | accessdate=26 March 2011 | first=Agnes | last=Milowka | date=23 Sep 2010 | publisher=National Geographic}}</ref> Her underwater photography has been included in multimedia library of the popular website creation software [[WebEasy Pro]]fessional (since 2007), distributed by Avanquest Software.
In 2010, when living in Florida, she laid over {{convert|4000|m}} of line across a number of cave systems, the most significant of which was Mission Spring. In August 2010, together with James Toland, she made the connection between Peacock Springs and Baptizing Spring, Florida adding over {{convert|3000|m}} of passage. She was the presenter and editor for TV series "Agnes Milowka Project" (2010) featuring underwater cave footage shot by [[Wes Skiles]], [[Karst Productions]].
Agnes Milowka was a speaker at a number of diving related conferences ([[OZTek]] 2009, [[EuroTek]] 2010). She acted as a [[stunt double]] for two female characters on the [[James Cameron]]-produced feature film ''[[Sanctum (film)|Sanctum]]'' (2011) and worked during the production as cave dive instructor to the actors. In 2011 she was nominated as Dive Rite Ambassador. One of her last jobs was as a diving supervisor on ''BIRTH'', a short film for the TRIMÄPEE fashion label. The movie has been dedicated in her name.
==Death== In February 2011, she ran out of air and died after parting company to explore a tight restriction, which necessitated going solo,<ref name=deepbluedive>{{cite news|last=Holden |first=Adam |title=Dedicated cave diver perishes |url=http://blog.deepbluedive.com/2011/03/04/dedicated-cave-diver-perishes/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121205160543/http://blog.deepbluedive.com/2011/03/04/dedicated-cave-diver-perishes/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 December 2012 |accessdate=18 July 2011 |newspaper=Deep Blue Dive Magazine |date=4 March 2011 }}</ref> in the Tank Cave near [[Tantanoola, South Australia|Tantanoola]] in the south east of [[South Australia]].<ref name=smh>{{cite news|last=Kappelle|first=Liza|title=Underwater caves a passion for lost diver|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/underwater-caves-a-passion-for-lost-diver-20110228-1bbec.html|accessdate=2 March 2011|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=28 February 2011}}</ref> In recognition of Milowka's achievements and legacy, The Agnes Milowka Memorial Environmental Science Award has been established by Mummu Media for underprivileged schools in the area of science, marine studies or exploration. In May 2011 Agnes Milowka [[wikt:posthumously|posthumously]] received the Exploration Award, in recognition of the outstanding and dedicated service to the [[National Speleological Society]] Cave Diving Section, USA.<ref name=NSS-CDS-award>{{cite web|first=Tony|last=Richardson|title=Aussie Cave Divers Receive NSS-CDS Awards|publisher=Cave Diving Down Under|url=http://www.cavediving.net.au/index.php/read/news/140-aussie-cave-divers-receive-nss-cds-awards|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> A number of geologic features have been named in memory and her original exploration work in Australia: "Ag's Dreamtime Passage" in the underwater [[Olwolgin Cave (Australia)|Olwolgin Cave]] on Nullarbor Plain,<ref name=Ag-s-Dream-Passage>{{cite journal|first=Paul|last=Hose|title=Survey of Unnamed Cave Roe Plains, WA|publisher=Cave Exploration Group Western Australia|year=2011}}</ref> "Agnes Chamber" in [[Davis Cave System (Australia)|Davis Cave System]], Bats Ridge, Victoria <ref name=Agnes-Chamber>{{cite journal|first=Peter|last=Freeman|title=Davies Cave Atlas|publisher=Victorian Speleological Association, Australia|year=2013}}</ref> and "Milowka Canal" in [[Elk River Cave (Australia)|Elk River Cave]], Victoria.<ref name=Milowka-Canal>{{cite journal|first=Peter|last=Freeman|title=MPEMC Atlas|publisher=Victorian Speleological Association, Australia|year=2013}}</ref> Her name has been featured in memoriam at 2011 Australian Academy of Cinema and Television Arts [[AACTA Awards|AACTA]] <ref name=AACTA-memoriam>{{cite journal|author=Australian Academy of Cinema and Television Arts|title=A Year in Review|publisher=AFI Australian Film Institute|year=2012}}</ref> and in popular sci-fi webcomic book [[Crimson Dark]], the alliance starship has been named A.W.S. Milowka.<ref name=CrimsonDark>{{cite web|first=David|last=Simon|title=Crimson Dark|publisher=David C. Simo|url=http://www.davidcsimon.com/crimsondark/index.php?view=comic&strip_id=463|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
==Author== Milowka authored articles on the subject of underwater exploration, and her experiences and work as a diver. These include:
* ''Let's Talk About... The S Word''<ref>{{cite journal|last=Milowka|first=Agnes|title=Let's Talk About... The S Word|journal=Tech Diving Mag|volume=6|url=http://www.techdivingmag.com/download006.asp|accessdate=31 August 2013}}</ref> *''Heaven is a place on earth''<ref name="A11">[[Cave Divers Association of Australia|CDAA]] Newsletter ''Guidelines'' No 102 Dec 2007</ref> *''Why Ginnie and I are like peas and carrots''<ref name="A10">CDAA Newsletter ''Guidelines'' No 105 Sep 2008</ref> *''Virgin Territory: Devil's Eye past the restriction''<ref name="A12">CDAA Newsletter ''Guidelines'' No 106 Dec 2008</ref> *''Deep holes in the ground that will blow your mind: Bahamas''<ref name="A06">CDAA Newsletter ''Guidelines'' No 108 June 2009</ref> *''Mission Spring''<ref name="A09">CDAA Newsletter ''Guidelines'' No 110 Dec 2009</ref> *''Cave diving in Victoria: Exploration of the Elk River streamway'' (co-authored with Jim Arundale)<ref name="A08">CDAA Newsletter ''Guidelines'' No 111 March 2010</ref> *''In the heart of Tiger's Eye''<ref name="A07">CDAA Newsletter ''Guidelines'' No 112 June 2010</ref> *''Virgin Territory: Devil's Eye Cave System Beyond Restriction''<ref name="A05">''Underwater Speleology'' Volume 36 Number 1, January/February/March</ref> *''Deep Holes. Unraveling The Mysteries Of The Bahamas''<ref name="A04">''Underwater Speleology'' Volume 36 Number 2, July/August/September</ref> *''Mission Spring Exploration''<ref name="A03">''Underwater Speleology'' Volume 36 Number 3, October/November/December</ref> *''The Elk River Streamway: A hump to a sump''<ref name="A02">''Underwater Speleology'' Volume 37 Number 1, January/February/March</ref> *''Eye of the Tiger: On expedition in Tassie''<ref name="A01">''Underwater Speleology'' Volume 37 Number 2, April/May/June 2010</ref> * ''The Taming Continues: The Peacock to Baptizing Connection'', co-author James Toland <ref name="A14">''Underwater Speleology'' Volume 38 Number 1, January/February/March 2011</ref>

Алексе́й Бата́лов | honorific_suffix = [[Hero of Socialist Labour|HSL]] [[People's Artist of the USSR|PAU]] | image = Aleksey Batalov.jpg | alt = | caption = Aleksey Batalov, 12 June 2006 | birth_name = Aleksey Vladimirovich Batalov | birth_date = {{Birth date|1928|11|20|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|6|15|1928|11|20|df=y}} | death_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | death_cause = Complications from a fall | other_names = | occupation = [[Actor]], [[Film director|Director]] | known_for = | spouse = {{marriage|Gitana Leontenko|1963}} | parents = Vladimir Batalov
Nina Olshevskaya }} '''Aleksey Vladimirovich Batalov''' ({{lang-ru|Алексе́й Влади́мирович Бата́лов}}; 20 November 1928 – 15 June 2017[http://kinoacademy.ru/page/list-members Cписок членов Национальной Академии кинематографических искусств и наук России].) was a [[USSR|Soviet]] and [[Russia]]n actor acclaimed for his portrayal of noble and positive characters. He was named a [[People's Artist of the USSR]] in 1976 and a [[Hero of Socialist Labour]] in 1989. ==Life and career== Batalov was born on 20 November 1928 in [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]], into a family associated with the theatre. His uncle Nikolay Batalov starred in [[Vsevolod Pudovkin]]'s classic ''Mother'' (1926). Modernist poet [[Anna Akhmatova]] was a family friend, and he painted a well-known portrait of her in 1952. Batalov joined the [[Moscow Art Theatre]] in 1953 but left three years later to concentrate on his career in film. During the [[Khrushchev Thaw]] he was one of the most recognizable actors in the [[Soviet Union]]. ''[[The Cranes Are Flying]]'' (1957) is his best-regarded film of the period, and the one which won [[Palme d'Or]] at the [[Cannes Film Festival]]. He also starred in [[Mikhail Romm]]'s ''[[Nine Days of One Year]]'' (1962). In 1967 he was a member of the jury of the [[5th Moscow International Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=1967 |title=5th Moscow International Film Festival (1967) |accessdate=9 December 2012 |work=MIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116194759/http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=1967 |archivedate=16 January 2013 }} In 1973 he was a member of the jury at the [[8th Moscow International Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=1973 |title=8th Moscow International Film Festival (1973) |accessdate=25 December 2012 |work=MIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116194922/http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=1973 |archivedate=16 January 2013 |df= }} During the 1960s and 1970s, Batalov became known for his fastidious approach towards choosing roles for himself. He appeared mostly in film adaptations of Russian classics, including [[Anton Chekhov]]'s '' [[The Lady with the Dog (film) |The Lady with the Dog]]'' (1960) and [[Bulgakov]]'s '' [[The Flight (film)|The Flight]]'' (1970). He also directed screen versions of [[Gogol]]'s ''[[The Overcoat]]'' (1960) and [[Yuri Olesha]]'s ''Three Fat Men'' (1966). In the 1970s he concentrated on professorship at the [[Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography]]. In 1979 Batalov was invited to play Gosha, a mill machinist, in the melodrama ''[[Moscow Does Not Believe in Tears]]''. After many hesitations, Batalov brilliantly played his part in the movie, which won him the [[USSR State Prize]]. The role was central to the film's Soviet message. As one character says in the picnic scene: "Seventy percent of my doctorate was due to Gosha's mechanical genius". After that, he effectively retired from acting and devoted his time to coaching new generations of film actors. [[Boris Yeltsin]] presented the Lifetime Achievement [[Nika Award]] to him in 2002. Batalov was awarded the [[State Prize of the Russian Federation]] (2005). In 2007 he received a Lifetime Achievement Award at the [[29th Moscow International Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=2007 |title=29th Moscow International Film Festival (2007) |accessdate=30 May 2013 |work=MIFF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421051129/http://www.moscowfilmfestival.ru/miff34/eng/archives/?year=2007 |archivedate=21 April 2013 }} In March 2014 he signed a letter in support of the position of the President of Russia [[Vladimir Putin]] on [[2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine|Russia's military intervention in Ukraine]].[http://m.glavcom.ua/news/170894-rossijskie-artisty-podderzhali-agressiju-putina-protiv-ukrainy-spisok.html Russian artists supported Putin's aggression against Ukraine (LIST)], [[Glavkom]] (11 March 2014){{cite web|title=Деятели культуры России — в поддержку позиции Президента по Украине и Крыму|url=http://mkrf.ru/press-tsentr/novosti/ministerstvo/deyateli-kultury-rossii-v-podderzhku-pozitsii-prezidenta-po-ukraine-i-krymu|publisher=Ministry for Culture of [[Russian Federation]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140311194202/mkrf.ru/press-tsentr/novosti/ministerstvo/deyateli-kultury-rossii-v-podderzhku-pozitsii-prezidenta-po-ukraine-i-krymu|archivedate=11 March 2014|df=dmy-all}} Batalov died on 15 June 2017 in [[Moscow]] from complications of a fall, which resulted in a hip fracture, at the age of 88.{{cite web|url=http://altapress.ru/story/v-moskve-skonchalsya-znamenitiy-akter-aleksey-batalov-203288|title=В Москве скончался знаменитый актер Алексей Баталов|publisher=Altapress.ru|accessdate=15 June 2017|date=15 June 2017}} ==Honours and awards== ;Awards of Russia and the USSR: * [[Hero of Socialist Labour]] (1989) * [[Order of Merit for the Fatherland]] **2nd class (20 November 2008) – for outstanding contribution to the development of national culture, many years of creative and educational activities **3rd class (10 November 1998) – for outstanding contributions to the development of national cinematography * Two [[Orders of Lenin]] (1967, 1989) * [[Honored Artist of the RSFSR]] (1964) * [[People's Artist of USSR]] (1976) * [[People's Artist of the RSFSR]] (1969) * [[USSR State Prize]] (1981) – for taking part in the movie ''Moscow does not believe in tears'' * [[State Prize of the RSFSR]] (1966) – for taking part in the movie ''Nine Days of One Year'' * [[State Prize of the Russian Federation]] (2005) * Russian Presidential Prize in Literature and Art in 1999 (17 February 2000) ;Foreign awards: * [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Bulgaria|Order of St. Cyril and {{more citations needed|date=September 2014}} "'''Banks of the Ohio'''",<ref>[[George Malcolm Laws|Laws]] F5</ref><ref>[[Roud Folk Song Index|Roud]] 157</ref> also known as "'''Down on the Banks of the Ohio'''", is a 19th-century [[murder ballad]], written by unknown authors, in which "Willie" invites his young lover for a walk during which she rejects his marriage proposal. Once they are alone on the river bank, he murders the young woman.
==Background== The song is superficially similar to other [[murder ballad]]s in the idiom such as [[Omie Wise]] and more especially [[Pretty Polly (ballad)|Pretty Polly]], which is also generally narrated in the first person by a killer called Willie. However, it differs significantly in the narrative; the killer explains why he killed his love, and spends much of the song expressing his sorrow and regret. Musically, it is distinguished by a long [[refrain]] which calmly reflects the love and the hopes for the future which he felt before the murder.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metrolyrics.com/banks-of-the-ohio-lyrics-johnny-cash.html |title=Banks of the Ohio - Johnny Cash |website=metrolyrics.com |accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref> This gives a different psychological tone to the song, and accompanying singers (or indeed the audience) the possibility of singing along in chorus.
Another not so well known version of the song is entitled "On the Banks of the Old Pedee".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KSrw1TaEJEAC&pg=PA265&lpg=PA265&dq=%22On+the+Banks+of+the+Old+Pedee%22&source=bl&ots=uC2ZPQ5JbW&sig=G2jGFexLD01SJs4KihhsbpA93Uc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QiycU_maCoWsO9vngOAN&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22On%20the%20Banks%20of%20the%20Old%20Pedee%22&f=false books.google.co.uk - On the Banks of the Old Pedee]</ref>
The lyrics are sometimes adapted for a female singer.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://genius.com/Dolly-parton-banks-of-the-ohio-lyrics |title=Banks of the Ohio - Dolly Parton |website=genius.com |accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref>
==Recordings== Commercial [[country music]] recordings started in 1927 with versions by Red Patterson's Piedmont Log Rollers (as "Down By The Banks Of The Ohio") and by [[G. B. Grayson|Grayson]] and [[Henry Whitter|Whitter]] (as "I'll Never Be Yours"). Other early country music stars who recorded the song included [[Ernest Stoneman]] (1928), The Callahan Brothers (1934), [[The Blue Sky Boys]] (1936), [[Clayton McMichen]] (1931) and [[Bill Monroe|The Monroe Brothers]] (1936). The Blue Sky Boys version appears in the soundtrack of the 1973 film ''[[Paper Moon (film)|Paper Moon]]''.
The song was recorded for the [[American folk music revival]] market by [[Bascom Lamar Lunsford]] (1953) and by the traditional singer Ruby Vass on a 1959 [[field recording]] made by [[Alan Lomax]] and issued on the LP (and subsequent CD) series ''Southern Journey''. It was recorded several times by [[Joan Baez]]: in 1959 as the opening track for the album ''[[Folksingers 'Round Harvard Square]]''; in 1961 in her album ''[[Joan Baez, Vol. 2]]''; on the 1968 [[Newport Folk Festival]] album; and other recordings. It was included on the 2011 CD compilation ''Voice of the People''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joanbaez.com/discsa.html |title=The Joan Baez Web Pages |publisher=Joanbaez.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-14}}</ref>
Alan Lomax made a further field recording in 1961 at his New York City apartment, featuring veteran singer [[Clarence Ashley]], accompanied by Fred Price (fiddle), and Clint Howard and [[Doc Watson]] (guitars). The recording, filmed by George Pickow and with sound by Jean Ritchie, was later used by [[Anna Lomax Wood]] for the short film ''Ballads, Blues and Bluegrass''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cld0f8ooXcg |title=Clarence Ashley with Doc Watson: The Banks of the Ohio (1961) |publisher=YouTube |date=2012-06-11 |accessdate=2014-06-14}}</ref> Another recording by this group was issued on ''Old Time Music at Clarence Ashley's'' reissued as [[Original Folkways Recordings: 1960–1962]] (1994). Also for Folkways, Doc Watson performed the song as a duet with [[Bill Monroe]] in 1963.
Other folk revival artist who recorded the song included the [[New Lost City Ramblers]] and [[Pete Seeger]]. Artists who returned the song to country music audiences included [[Johnny Cash]] with [[The Carter Family]], [[Porter Wagoner]] and [[Dolly Parton]]. Other recording were made by [[The Wolfe Tones]], [[Arlo Guthrie]] (as "Arloff Boguslavaki," on the 1972 [[Earl Scruggs]] album ''I Saw the Light''), [[Dave Guard]] and the [[Whiskeyhill Singers]], Mike Ireland and Holler, [[Gangstagrass]] featuring Alexa Dirks also giving a faithful rendition on their 2014 album ''Broken Hearts and Stolen Money''.
[[Olivia Newton-John]] recorded an arrangement of the song by [[Marvin, Welch & Farrar|John Farrar and Bruce Welch]] in 1971, for her album ''[[If Not for You (album)|If Not for You]]''. It was released as the second single from the album and was successful in the UK, peaking at number six. It was her first number one hit in Australia<ref name="go-setbanks">{{cite web|url=http://www.poparchives.com.au/gosetcharts/1971/19710612.html|title=Pop Archives: Go-Set National Top 60 (June 12, 1971)}}</ref> and reached number 9 in South Africa <ref>http://www.rock.co.za/files/sa_charts_1969_1989_songs_(A-B).html</ref> but failed to reach the top forty in Canada and the US, peaking at number sixty-six and ninety-four, respectively.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|last=Viglione|first=Joe|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/if-not-for-you-mw0000739358|title= Olivia Newton-John – ''If Not for You''|publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=2012-12-22}}</ref><ref name="canadabanks">{{cite web|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?&file_num=nlc008388.7595&type=1&interval=20&PHPSESSID=a3oevvmb6o97qcpcgfcn086b00|title=Collections Canada: RPM Top 100 Singles (November 20, 1971)}}</ref> The distinctive [[basso]] backing vocals were provided by English musician and vocal session arranger [[Mike Sammes]]. Tony Rice recorded the song on his [[Tony Rice (album)|eponymous 1977 album]]. A [[Swedish language|Swedish]] version, recorded by [[Ann-Louise Hanson]], is entitled "Tag emot en utsträckt hand".<ref>{{Citation|last=Lennart Ljung|title=Ann-Louise Hanson - Tag emot en utsträckt hand (1990)|date=2015-08-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dELufo4cX18|accessdate=2017-09-01}}</ref>
The song appears, and gives the title for, the 2013 album ''Oh, Willie, Please...'' a collection of folk murder ballads, by [[Indie folk|alt-folk]] musical project [[Vandaveer]]. The band made a live [[Gramophone record|78 acetate recording]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JtMJvKt4SJQ |title=Vandaveer - Oh Willie Please (New Album) - PledgeMusic Launch Video |publisher=YouTube |date=2012-04-22 |accessdate=2014-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=from The 78 Project PRO 2 years ago Not Yet Rated |url=http://vimeo.com/38776953 |title=The 78 Project: Vandaveer - "Banks of the Ohio" on Vimeo |publisher=Vimeo.com |date=2012-03-19 |accessdate=2014-06-14}}</ref>
==Legacy== The song and its title served as the theme song for, and title of, a long-running radio series broadcast of [[bluegrass music]] on [[WAMU]]-[[PBS]] and Bluegrass Country, hosted by Fred Bartenstein and produced for the [[International Bluegrass Music Museum]], near the [[Ohio River]] in [[Owensboro, Kentucky]].

{{use British English|date=August 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Vishal Mehrotra | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[India]] | disappeared_date = 29 July 1981 (aged 8) | disappeared_place = [[Putney|Putney, South London]] | nationality = [[Indian people|Indian]] | body_discovered = 25 February 1982 | education = | height = | weight = | mother = Aruba Mehrita | father = Vishambar Mehrotra | known for = }}
'''Vishal Mehrotra''' was an 8-year-old boy who was abducted from [[Putney|Putney, South London]] on 29 July 1981.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/paedophile-sidney-cookes-potential-links-5793887|title=Paedophile Sidney Cooke's potential links to murder of boy, 8, ignored by police|last=Corke|first=Jonathan|date=30 May 2015|work=Daily Mirror|access-date=18 August 2018}}</ref> Vishal's partial remains were discovered 25 February 1982 on an isolated farm in [[Sussex]]. The perpetrators were never identified and no charges have been filed in connection with these events.
==Background== Vishal was born in India and the Mehrotra family came to the UK in 1978.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=|title=Tragic end to missing boy hunt – Skeleton mystery|last=|first=|date=4 March 1982|work=The Herald|access-date=|publisher=|others=|month=}}</ref> Vishal's father, Vishambar Mehrotra, was a solicitor at the time of the disappearance<ref name=":1" /> and is now a retired magistrate.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/nov/19/paedophile-ring-allegations-elm-house|title=Paedophile ring allegations: police are failing us, murdered boy’s father says|last=Laville|first=Sandra|last2=Halliday|first2=Josh|date=19 November 2014|work=The Guardian|language=en|access-date=18 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/murdered-boys-father-says-police-ignored-informant-8b9d32s6wj6|title=Murdered boy’s father says police ignored informant|last=O’Neill|first=Sean|date=19 November 2014|work=The Times|access-date=19 August 2018|language=en|issn=0140-0460}}</ref> Vishal's mother, Aruba Mehrita, was estranged from her husband and lived in India at the time of the disappearance.<ref name=":1" /> The family lived on Holmbush Road, [[Putney]], [[South London]].<ref name=":1" />
Vishal was described as bright and independent. He travelled to his school in Queens Gate every day on his own.<ref name=":1" />
==Day of the disappearance== 29 July 1981 was the day of the [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer|wedding of Charles and Diana]]. Vishal had been watching the royal wedding with his father, sister and nanny.<ref name=":1" /> The family were walking home through the crowded streets and Vishal was walking ahead of his family.<ref name=":0" /> At [[East Putney tube station|East Putney]] tube station Vishal parted company with his family and went home alone while his sister and nanny went shopping.<ref name=":1" /> The family last saw him cross the road near Carlton Drive.<ref name=":1" />
==Initial investigation== The initial police investigation involved searching the vicinity of the disappearance from the air with a thermal camera as well as ground searches of common land and the river Thames.<ref name=":1" /> Initially, it was thought that Vishal could have tried to travel to India and this line of inquiry was investigated by international police.<ref name=":1" />
Between the disappearance and the discovery of the body the police investigated hundreds of sightings and interviewed over 14,000 people.<ref name=":1" />
==Discovery of the body== On 25 February 1982 two men, who were shooting pigeons, discovered a skull, seven rib bones and a section of vertebrae at Alder Copse, Durleigh Marsh Farm, [[Rogate]] near [[Chichester]].<ref name=":1" /> The bones appeared to have been disturbed by foxes and were found buried in a bog at a depth of around two feet.<ref name=":1" />
Following the discovery, a large scale excavation and search involving about 30 police officers took place.<ref name=":1" /> This uncovered more bones, however, no clothing was found.<ref name=":1" /> The bones were taken to London for forensic investigation.<ref name=":1" /> Initially, police believed that the body had been buried around 29 July 1981.<ref name=":1" />
==Subsequent investigations== Police initially believed that Vishal may have been abducted by someone with local knowledge of the Durleigh Marsh Farm area.<ref name=":1" />
In March 2015, the BBC reported that the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] had referred itself to the [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] following allegations of corruption.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-31717179|title=Boy's 1981 death to be probed by IPCC|date=3 March 2015|work=BBC News|access-date=18 August 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In May 2015, the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' newspaper reported that a 2005 Sussex Police review, by ex-detective Alwyn Evans, had been released to the paper following a [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|FOI]] request.<ref name=":2" /> The review mentioned [[Sidney Cooke|Sydney Cooke]] a number of times and showed that Cooke had begun to be linked with abductions in the early 1980s.<ref name=":2" /> Cooke was a fairground worker and the report revealed that there were two fairs in the area when Vishal vanished.<ref name=":2" /> The findings were apparently not acted upon.<ref name=":2" /> Roger Stoodley, who retired as the detective leading the Cooke gang investigation in 1992, stated that the disappearances of Vishal (and another boy [[Disappearance of Martin Allen|Martin Allen]]) were in keeping with the gangs [[modus operandi]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/paedophile-gang-may-have-killed-17-more-children-qm7mxjs9tvf|title=Paedophile gang ‘may have killed 17 more children’|last=O’Neill|first=David Brown, Georgie Keate and Sean|date=20 November 2014|work=The Times|access-date=21 August 2018|language=en|issn=0140-0460}}</ref> The gang were known to have abducted boys who they found walking on their own.<ref name=":4" />
== Elm Guest House == A few months after his son's disappearance Vishambar Mehrotra said that he had been contacted by an unidentified man thought to be in his twenties.<ref name=":0" /> This man suggested that Vishal had been abducted, and that this event may be connected to a group of influential paedophiles associated with the [[Elm Guest House claims and controversy|Elm Guest House]].<ref name=":0" /> The man stated that he had informed the police but they had not followed up his report.<ref name=":0" /> Vishambar gave a recording of the telephone conversation to detectives, however, they dismissed it as a crank call and it was not followed up.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" /> The location of Vishal's disappearance was less than a mile from the Elm Guest House.<ref name=":0" />
