{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2013}}{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}}{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Dinakaran'' attack case}} The '''''Dinakaran'' attack case''' was a [[Firebombing|firebomb]] attack by [[M. K. Alagiri]]'s supporters<ref>{{cite web | url=https://rsf.org/en/news/three-newspaper-employees-killed-arson-attack-tamil-nadu-state | title=Three newspaper employees killed in arson attack in Tamil Nadu state | publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]] | date=10 May 2007 | accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.indiatoday.in/magazine/states/story/20070521-karunanidhis-family-drama-for-power-748583-2007-05-21 | title=M.Karunanidhi's 50 years were on the cost of Tamil daily Dinakaran | publisher=[[India Today]] | work=S. S. Jeevan | date=21 May 2007 | accessdate=2 August 2018}}</ref> on 9 May 2007 on the [[Madurai]] office of ''[[Dinakaran]]'', a [[Tamil language|Tamil]] newspaper, which resulted in the deaths of three people.<ref name="toi-incident">{{cite news|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-05-09/india/27884568_1_m-k-azhagiri-security-personnel-dmk|title=3 people killed in Dinakaran attack |work=[[The Times of India]]|date=9 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> The attack was a response to a survey published by ''Dinakaran'' on who people preferred as the future heir of [[M. Karunanidhi]], chief of the political party [[Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] (DMK). During mass protests throughout the region, the offices of the newspaper were firebombed and two press employees and a private security guard died. 17 people were charged by the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]], but were all acquitted by the district court. [[Dayanidhi Maran]] resigned from the [[Cabinet of India|Union Cabinet]], where he had been the Minister for Communications and Information Technology, as a result of the controversy surrounding the attack, which created a rift between him and DMK.
==Background==
[[M. K. Stalin]] and [[M. K. Azhagiri]], sons of DMK chief [[M. Karunanidhi]] were in a [[Karunanidhi_family#Azhagiri_Vs_Stalin|succession battle]] to be the political heir of Karunanidhi. <!-- TODO: Develop the section with full text on succession battle instead of linking the section. -------------------------M. K. Stalin's loyalist [[Tha. Kiruttinan]] was murdered and Azhagiri was arrested in connection to the [[Tha. Kiruttinan murder case|case]] and was on trial<ref>{{cite web|title=In the DMK, it's brother vs brother|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2007/may/09look-tn.htm|publisher=Rediff|date=9 May 2013|accessdate=22 July 2013 |deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6IIp5XH16?url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2007/may/09look-tn.htm|archivedate=22 July 2013}}</ref> although he was later acquitted in 2008<ref name="ThaKiruttinan judgement">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/azhagiri-12-others-acquitted-in-kiruttinan-murder-case/article1254656.ece|title=Azhagiri, 12 others acquitted in Kiruttinan murder case|work=The Hindu|date=9 May 2008|accessdate=22 July 2013}} </ref>--------------------------------------- --> In May 2007, the newspaper ''Dinakaran'' caused controversy when it published the results of a series of opinion polls conducted by [[A.C. Nielsen Co.]] which appeared to show that Stalin had more public approval than his elder brother Azhagiri – 70% of those polled preferred Stalin, while only 2% preferred Azhagiri (another 2% supported [[M. K. Kanimozhi]], daughter of Karunanidhi).<ref name="toi-incident"/><ref name="hindu-incident">{{cite news|author=S. Vijay Kumar|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/3-killed-as-newspaper-office-is-set-on-fire/article1840356.ece|title=3 killed as newspaper office is set on fire|work=The Hindu|date=10 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> The newspaper is part of the [[Sun Group]] which is owned by [[Kalanidhi Maran]], who is grand-nephew of Karunanidhi and brother of DMK politician and ex-Union Minister [[Dayanidhi Maran]].
==Incident== On 9 May 2007, agitated by the results of the survey, DMK cadres in the southern district of Tamil Nadu, particularly the supporters of Azhagiri, engaged in protests at [[Kamuthi]], [[Dindigul]], [[Tirunelveli]], [[Virudhunagar]] and [[Tuticorin]] and various places in the [[Theni district]].<ref>{{cite news|agency=PTI|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-05-09/india/27887875_1_newspaper-office-dmk-tamil-nadu|title=DMK activists set fire to Tamil daily office, 1 killed|work=The Times of India|date=9 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> At Madurai, they protested by burning copies of the newspapers and raising slogans against the survey and the Maran brothers. They also held a [[road block protest]], threw stones, and set seven buses on fire.<ref>{{cite web|title=மதுரை தினகரன்-சன் டிவி அலுவலகம் மீது அழகிரி ஆதரவாளர்கள் பயங்கர தாக்குதல்:3 பேர் பலி- 7 பஸ்களுக்கு தீ வைப்பு|url=http://tamil.oneindia.in/news/2007/05/09/alagiri.html|publisher=[[OneIndia]] Tamil|language=Tamil|date=9 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> Anticipating trouble, a team of anti-riot police under the Deputy Superintendent of Madurai were deployed outside the offices of the media group. Despite the police presence, a group of men hurled stones at the building housing the offices of ''Dinakaran'', [[Sun TV (India)|Sun TV]] and [[Tamil Murasu (India)|Tamil Murasu]], all belonging to Sun Group. They also threw [[petrol bomb]]s and set the building on fire, resulting in the death by [[asphyxiation]] of two employees and a private security guard.<ref name="hindu-incident"/>
The staff of the newspaper blocked the [[National Highway 45B (India)|Chennai Madurai highway]], demanding the arrest of Azhagiri, charging him with responsibility for the incident.<ref name="hindu-incident"/> The staff also accused the police of inaction.<ref name="HinduPoliceInaction">{{cite news|author=Special Correspondent|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/police-blamed-for-inaction/article1840354.ece|title=Police blamed for inaction|work=The Hindu|date=10 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> Madurai Superintendent T. S. Anbu said there was no deliberate dereliction of duty by the police; however, the Director General of Police, D. Mukharjee, later admitted dereliction of duty by policemen and ordered a probe be conducted by a senior police official.<ref name="CBI-transfer">{{cite news|author=S. Vijay Kumar|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/cbi-takes-over-investigation-into-dinakaran-attack-case/article1844864.ece|title=CBI takes over investigation into Dinakaran attack case|work=The Hindu|date=20 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
Kalanidhi Maran, managing director of Sun Networks, called this incident an "attack on [[Freedom of press|freedom of the press]]", and vowed to fight for justice.<ref name="KMaranReply">{{cite news|agency=PTI|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-05-09/india/27877239_1_dinakaran-office-kalanidhi-maran-sun-network|title=Kalanidhi Maran to fight state, Centre for justice|work=The Times of India|date=9 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> M. Karunanidhi condemned the attack, calling it "an attack on democracy and press freedom", and promised legal action. On the whole issue of political heirs, he said that "there is no place for dynastic succession in the DMK".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/karunanidhi-no-place-for-dynastic-succession/article1840355.ece|title=Karunanidhi: no place for dynastic succession|work=The Hindu|date=10 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> He later told the [[Tamil Nadu Assembly]] that he was puzzled by the timing of the survey, and had told the ''Dinakaran'' management that such polls may create unnecessary problems, but that the newspaper had ignored his advice.<ref name="frontline"/> Several journalists' associations condemned the attack and submitted a memorandum calling for immediate police action,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/journalists-fora-to-submit-memorandum/article1841367.ece|title=Journalists' fora to submit memorandum|work=The Hindu|date=12 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> urging the government to bring charges against not only the assailants but also "the persons behind the conspiracy".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/journalists-mark-protest-against-arson-attack-on-madurai-newspaper-office/article1840779.ece|title=Journalists mark protest against arson attack on Madurai newspaper office|work=The Hindu|date=11 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref>
[[Dayanidhi Maran]], who is usually present along with Karunanidhi on most party functions, stayed away from the celebration of Karunanidhi's 50th year as legislator, which was attended by [[Manmohan Singh]] and [[Sonia Gandhi]]. DMK's administrative committee suggested that Dayanidhi Maran be removed from the Union Cabinet for violating party discipline. Maran, however, resigned voluntarily, insisting that he had never taken part in anti-party activities and that someone was misleading the party chief.<ref name="frontline">{{cite web |last=Subramanian |first=T.S. |title=Mayhem in Madurai |url=http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl2410/stories/20070601004402200.htm |publisher=The Hindu Frontline |accessdate=22 July 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IJ32ALNj?url=http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl2410/stories/20070601004402200.htm |archivedate=22 July 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[Kalaignar TV]], a new channel owned by the Karunanidhi family, was launched as a potential rival to Sun TV when the tensions between Karunanidhi and the Maran brothers were at their highest.<ref>{{cite news|author=D Govardan|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2007-06-14/news/28419240_1_raj-tv-raj-television-network-gemini-tv|title=Karunanidhi family owns New TV channel Kalaignar|work=The Economic Times|date=14 June 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> The government also announced the formation of [[Tamil Nadu Arasu Cable TV Corporation Limited]], a new [[multiple-system operator]] which intended to end the monopoly of [[Sun Cable Vision]].{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} In December 2008, the Marans made peace with the Karunanidhi family.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/marans-patch-up-with-karunanidhi/article1387063.ece|title=Marans patch up with Karunanidhi|work=The Hindu|date=2 December 2008|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref>
===Court proceedings===
The management of ''Dinakaran'' accused the police of ignoring their formal complaint, which specifically sought action against Azhagiri, and instead choose to act on a ''[[suo motu]]'' complaint which did not include his name.<ref>{{cite news|author=S. Vijay Kumar|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/police-ignored-our-complaint-says-dinakaran/article1840702.ece|title=Police ignored our complaint, says Dinakaran|work=The Hindu|date=11 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref>
On 16 May 2009, police arrested their prime suspect, P. Pandi (aka "Attack" Pandi), who later confessed to spearheading the attack.<ref name="AttackPandiNabbed">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/prime-suspect-in-dinakaran-office-attack-case-held/article1842929.ece|title=Prime suspect in ''Dinakaran'' office attack case held|work=The Hindu|date=16 May 2007|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> The case was transferred to the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]],<ref name="CBI-transfer"/> which named 17 accused in a 32-page charge sheet, including a [[Deputy Superintendent]] charged with dereliction of duty.<ref name="chargesheet">{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/1113953/report-16-chargesheeted-in-dinakaran-attack-case|title=16 chargesheeted in Dinakaran attack case|date=6 August 2007|accessdate=23 July 2013|publisher = DNA India}}</ref> In December 2009, all 17 were acquitted by the district sessions court,<ref>{{cite news|author=Special Correspondent|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/all-acquitted-in-dinakaran-case/article91128.ece|title=All acquitted in Dinakaran case|work=The Hindu|date=10 December 2009|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> which claimed that the case had not been proven beyond all reasonable doubt. In March 2011, the [[Madras High Court]] allowed an appeal challenging this decision, despite a delay in filing the same. The CBI contended that the trial court "ought to have considered the evidentiary value of Prosecution Witness 1", even though he had "turned hostile" during the proceedings.<ref>{{cite news|author=Mohamed Imranullah S.|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/court-condones-delay-in-filing-appeal-in-dinakaran-attack-case/article1537881.ece|title=Court condones delay in filing appeal in 'Dinakaran' attack case|location=MADURAI|work=The Hindu|date=14 March 2011|accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref>

{{More footnotes|date=September 2010}} {{Individualism sidebar}} An '''individual''' is that which exists as a distinct [[entity]]. '''Individuality''' (or [[wikt:selfhood|selfhood]]) is the state or quality of being an individual; particularly of being a person separate from other people and possessing his or her own [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|needs]] or [[Personal goal setting|goals]], [[right]]s and [[moral responsibility|responsibilities]]. The exact definition of an individual is important in the fields of [[biology]], [[law]], and [[philosophy]].
From the 15th century and earlier (and also today within the fields of [[statistics]] and [[metaphysics]]) ''individual'' meant "[[divisible|indivisible]]", typically describing any numerically singular thing, but sometimes meaning "a person". From the 17th century on, ''individual'' indicates separateness, as in [[individualism]].<ref>Abbs 1986, cited in Klein 2005, pp. 26–27</ref>
Although individuality and individualism are commonly considered to mature with age/time and experience/wealth, a [[sanity|sane]] adult [[human|human being]] is usually considered by the [[State (polity)|state]] as an "individual person" in law, even if the person denies individual [[culpability]] ("I followed instructions"). An individual person is [[accountability|accountable]] for their actions/decisions/instructions, subject to [[prosecution]] in both national and international law, from the time that they have reached [[age of majority]], often though not always more or less coinciding with the granting of [[voting right]]s, [[tax]] and [[military duty|military duties]]/ individual [[Right to keep and bear arms|right to bear arms]] (protected only under certain constitutions). In line with [[hierarchy]], ultimate individual human reward for [[Social status|success]] and responsibility for [[failure]] is nonetheless found at the top of [[society|human society]].
==Law== in [[International law]]: :All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood.<ref>Article 1 of the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/UDHR/Documents/UDHR_Translations/eng.pdf</ref>
in [[Law of the United States|American law]]: :A natural person is a human being. A legal person is an entity such as a company, which is regarded in law as having its own 'legal personality'.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Jon Rush|author2=Michael Ottley|title=Business Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s2gFZhuB5boC&pg=PA4|year=2006|publisher=Cengage Learning |page=4}}</ref>
The ''Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of Law'' states: A "natural person" is "A human being as distinguished from person (as a corporation) created by operation of law.<ref>{{cite book|author=Merriam-Webster, Inc|title=Merriam-Webster's Dictionary of Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JYs74quLWLIC&pg=PA323|year=1996|page=323}}</ref> A 1910 legal dictionary states: "Individual: As a noun, this term denotes a single person as distinguished from a group or class, and also, very commonly, a private or natural person as distinguished from a partnership, corporation, or association."<ref>{{cite book|author=Henry Campbell Black|title=A Law Dictionary Containing Definitions of the Terms and Phrases of American and English Jurisprudence, Ancient and Modern. 2nd edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PNQgVoT2_aQC&pg=PA618|year=1910|page=618}}</ref>
==Philosophy== ===Buddhism=== In [[Buddhism]], the concept of the individual lies in [[anatman]], or "no-self." According to anatman, the individual is really a series of interconnected processes that, working together, give the appearance of being a single, separated whole. In this way, anatman, together with [[anicca]], resembles a kind of [[bundle theory]]. Instead of an atomic, indivisible self distinct from reality, the individual in Buddhism is understood as an interrelated part of an ever-changing, impermanent universe (see [[Interdependence]], [[Nondualism]], [[Reciprocity (social psychology)|Reciprocity]]).
===Empiricism=== Early [[Empiricism|empiricists]] such as [[Ibn Tufail]]<ref name=Russell>G. A. Russell (1994), ''The 'Arabick' Interest of the Natural Philosophers in Seventeenth-Century England'', pp. 224–62, [[Brill Publishers]], {{ISBN|90-04-09459-8}}.</ref> in early 12th century Islamic Spain, and [[John Locke]] in late 17th century England, [[Hayy ibn Yaqdhan#Empiricism, tabula rasa, nature versus nurture|introduced the idea]] of the individual as a [[tabula rasa]] ("blank slate"), shaped from birth by experience and education. This ties into the idea of the liberty and rights of the individual, society as a [[social contract]] between [[Rationality|rational]] individuals, and the beginnings of [[individualism]] as a doctrine.
===Hegel<!--linked from 'Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel'-->=== [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]] regarded history as the gradual evolution of Mind as it tests its own concepts against the external world.{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} Each time the mind applies its concepts to the world, the concept is revealed to be only partly true, within a certain context; thus the mind continually revises these incomplete concepts so as to reflect a fuller reality (commonly known as the process of thesis, antithesis, and synthesis). The individual comes to rise above his or her own particular viewpoint,{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} and grasps that he or she is a part of a greater whole{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} insofar as he or she is bound to family, a social context, and/or a political order.
===Existentialism=== With the rise of [[existentialism]], [[Søren Kierkegaard]] rejected Hegel's notion of the individual as subordinated to the forces of history. Instead, he elevated the individual's subjectivity and capacity to choose his or her own fate. Later Existentialists built upon this notion. [[Friedrich Nietzsche]], for example, examines the individual's need to define his/her own self and circumstances in his concept of [[the will to power]] and the heroic ideal of the [[Übermensch]]. The individual is also central to [[Sartre]]'s philosophy, which emphasizes individual authenticity, responsibility, and [[free will]]. In both Sartre and Nietzsche (and in [[Nikolai Berdyaev]]), the individual is called upon to create his or her own values, rather than rely on external, socially imposed codes of morality.
===Objectivism=== [[Ayn Rand]]'s [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]] regards every human as an independent, sovereign entity who possesses an inalienable right to his or her own life, a right derived from his or her nature as a rational being. Individualism and Objectivism hold that a civilized society, or any form of association, cooperation or peaceful coexistence among humans, can be achieved only on the basis of the recognition of [[individual rights]] — and that a group, as such, has no rights other than the individual rights of its members. The principle of individual rights is the only moral base of all groups or associations. Since only an individual man or woman can possess rights, the expression "individual rights" is a redundancy (which one has to use for purposes of clarification in today's intellectual chaos), but the expression "[[collective rights]]" is a contradiction in terms. Individual rights are not subject to a public vote; a [[Tyranny of the majority|majority]] has no right to vote away the rights of a [[minority group|minority]]; the political function of rights is precisely to protect minorities from oppression by majorities (and the smallest minority on earth is the individual).<ref>Ayn Rand, [http://www.aynrandlexicon.com/lexicon/individualism.html ''"Individualism"'']. Ayn Rand Lexicon.</ref><ref>Ayn Rand (1961), [http://aynrandlexicon.com/lexicon/individualrights.html ''"Individual Rights"'']. Ayn Rand Lexicon.</ref>
==Biology<!--Linked from 'Extraterrestrial life'-->== In [[biology]], the question of the individual is related to the definition of an [[organism]], which is an important question in biology and [[philosophy of biology]], despite there having been little work devoted explicitly to this question.<ref name=Wilson>{{Cite journal | last = Wilson | first = R | title = The biological notion of individual | journal = Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy | year = 2007|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/biology-individual/}}</ref> An individual organism is not the only kind of individual that is considered as a "unit of [[Selection (biology)|selection]]".<ref name=Wilson/> [[Gene]]s, [[genome]]s, or groups may function as individual units.<ref name=Wilson/>
[[Asexual reproduction]] occurs in some colonial organisms so that the individuals are genetically identical. Such a colony is called a [[genet (biology)|genet]], and an individual in such a population is referred to as a ramet. The colony, rather than the individual, functions as a unit of selection. In other colonial organisms the individuals may be closely related to one another but differ as a result of [[sexual reproduction]].

'''Kathryn Aalto''' is an American landscape designer, historian, educator and New York Times Bestselling author<ref name=NYTFeb>[https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2016-02-07/travel/list.html New York Times Bestseller List, Travel, February 2016]</ref> based in [[Exeter, England]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Youlden|first1=Mary|title=Exeter Lives: Kathryn Aalto|url=http://www.theexeterdaily.co.uk/news/blogs/exeter-lives-kathryn-aalto|accessdate=17 May 2016|publisher=The Exeter Daily|date=31 August 2013}}</ref>
== Early life == Kathryn Aalto grew up between San Francisco and the Sierras in California's San Joaquin Valley where she developed a lifelong interest in landscape history, design and literature of place. She was educated at the [[University of California at Berkeley]], [[Western Washington University]], the London College of Garden Design<ref>{{cite web|title=London College of Garden Design|url=http://www.lcgd.org.uk/|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref> and the [[University of Bristol]], from which she received a Bachelor’s in English, a Master’s in English, a Diploma in Garden Design and a Master’s in Garden History.
== Career ==
=== Books === Kathryn Aalto is best known for her book, ''The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh: A Walk Through the Forest that Inspired the Hundred Acre Wood,''<ref name="The Oregonian">{{cite news|last1=Eastman|first1=Janet|title=Winnie-the-Pooh's real forest: Meet author Kathryn Aalto (photos)|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/hg/index.ssf/2016/02/natural_world_of_winnie-the-po_1.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=The Oregonian|date=3 February 2016}}</ref> published in 2015 by [[Timber Press]], which became a [[New York Times Bestseller]] in February 2016.<ref name=NYTFeb /> It was featured on NPR's "All Things Considered" on October 26, 2015 and selected as a People magazine Best Pick in Nonfiction in November 2015. Extensive coverage of the book included an article<ref>{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Adrian|title=The real forest that inspired the stories of Winnie-the-Pooh|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/home/the-real-forest-that-inspired-the-stories-of-winnie-the-pooh/2015/11/10/7cedc4bc-8331-11e5-a7ca-6ab6ec20f839_story.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=The Washington Post|date=11 November 2015}}</ref> and review<ref>{{cite news|last1=Quattlebaum|first1=Mary|title=‘The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh’ is a honey pot of nostalgia|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/books/the-natural-world-of-winnie-the-pooh-is-a-honey-pot-of-nostalgia/2015/10/15/58914cd6-63bc-11e5-b38e-06883aacba64_story.html|accessdate=24 June 2016|agency=The Washington Post|date=15 October 2015}}</ref> in [[The Washington Post]], articles in [[The Boston Globe]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tuttle|first1=Kate|title=Landscape historian Kathryn Aalto on Winnie-the-Pooh’s forest|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/books/2015/11/14/story-behind-book-landscape-historian-kathryn-aalto-winnie-pooh-forest/2iLvjEarwFbSvDwKKEydJM/story.html|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=The Boston Globe|date=14 November 2015}}</ref> and [[The Oregonian]],<ref name="The Oregonian"/> as well as radio interviews on NPR,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shapiro|first1=Ari|title=The real forest that inspired the stories of Winnie-the-Pooh|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/01/18/463503941/the-real-woods-behind-winnie-the-poohs-forest|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=Northeast Public Radio (NPR)|date=18 January 2016}}</ref> WAMC<ref>{{cite news|last1=Donahue|first1=Joe|title=The Natural World Of Winnie-The-Pooh|url=http://wamc.org/term/preseration#stream/0|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=WAMC|date=21 October 2015}}</ref> and MPR.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mumford|first1=Tracy|title=Inside Winnie-the-Pooh's real Hundred Acre Wood|url=http://www.mprnews.org/story/2015/11/04/bcst-books-hundred-acre-wood|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=MPR|date=4 November 2015}}</ref> She is also the author of Nature and Human Intervention<ref>{{Cite book|title=Nature and Human Intervention|website=Amazon|id= {{ASIN|0957035500|country=uk}}}}</ref> for Italian garden designer Luciano Guibbilei.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Heather|first1=Duncan|title=New Book by Luciano Giubbilei: Nature and Human Intervention|url=http://gardendesigncourses.blogspot.co.uk/2011/10/new-book-by-luciano-giubbilei-nature.html|accessdate=24 June 2016|publisher=Oxford College of Garden Design|date=October 2011}}</ref>
*{{cite book|last1=Aalto|first1=Kathryn|title=The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh: A Walk Through the Forest that Inspired the Hundred Acre Wood|date=2015|publisher=[[Timber Press]]|isbn=978-1604695991}}.<ref>[http://www.gilbertwhiteshouse.org.uk/2016/05/qa-kathryn-aalto/ Gilbert White & The Oates Collections, Q&A With Kathryn Aalto, ''12 May 2016'']</ref> This book appeared on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|New York Times bestseller list]] in February 2016.<ref name=NYTFeb /> *{{cite book|last1=Aalto|first1=Kathryn|last2=Giubbilei|first2=Luciano|title=Nature and Human Intervention|date=2011|publisher=Luciano Giubbilei Design|isbn=9780957035508}}
=== Teaching and public speaking === As an educator, she has taught American Literature of Nature and Place, Critical Thinking and Composition and other writing courses at [[Western Washington University]], [[Everett Community College]] and [[Exeter College, Exeter|Exeter College]] where she is an adjunct lecturer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Speaker Profile - Kathryn Aalto|url=http://www.scbwi.org/speakers/kathryn-aalto|website=Society of Children’s Book Writers and Illustrators|accessdate=17 May 2016}}</ref> A dynamic public speaker, Kathryn Aalto lectures widely, both in the United States and England, on landscape history and creative careers to libraries, schools, historical societies, botanical gardens, universities and civic clubs. Past venues have included Harvard Universities [[Arnold Arboretum]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Arnold Arboretum|title=The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh: The Forest that Inspired the Hundred Acre Wood|url=https://my.arboretum.harvard.edu/info.aspx?ActivityID=2254|website=The Arnold Arboretum|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=15 November 2015}}</ref> [[The New York Public Library]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=The New York Public Library|title=Children's Literary Salon: The Natural World of Winnie-the-Pooh|url=http://www.nypl.org/events/programs/2015/10/17/childrens-literary-salon-natural-world-winnie-pooh|website=The New York Public Library|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=17 October 2015}}</ref> the [[Northwest Flower and Garden Show]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Northwest Flower and Garden Show|title=KATHRYN AALTO: U.K. WRITER, DESIGNER AND AUTHOR, THE NATURAL WORLD OF WINNIE-THE-POOH|url=https://www.gardenshow.com/seminars/speaker-info/kathryn-aalto/|website=Northwest Flower and Garden Show|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=17 February 2016}}</ref> and the Virginia Festival of the Book.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Virginia Festival of the Book 2016|title=Speaker: Kathryn Aalto|url=http://vabook16.vfhblogs.org/participant/kathryn-aalto/|website=Virginia Festival of the Book|accessdate=17 May 2016|date=17 March 2016}}</ref> She also gives inspirational talks on interdisciplinary careers, creativity and writing.
== Personal life == Kathryn Aalto resides in Exeter, England. She has lived in [[Escalon]], [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], [[Seattle]], [[Monroe, Washington|Monroe]] and [[Exeter, England]]

{{short description|Self-reproducing patterns in a particular cellular automaton rule, investigated in 1984 by Christopher Langton}} [[Image:Langtons Loop.png|frame|right|Langton's Loop, in the starting configuration.]]
'''Langton's loops''' are a particular "species" of [[artificial life]] in a [[cellular automaton]] created in 1984 by [[Christopher Langton]]. They consist of a loop of cells containing genetic information, which flows continuously around the loop and out along an "arm" (or [[pseudopod]]), which will become the daughter loop. The "genes" instruct it to make three left turns, completing the loop, which then disconnects from its parent.
== History ==
In 1952 [[John von Neumann]] created the first cellular automaton (CA) with the goal of creating a self-replicating machine.<ref name=TSRA>{{cite web|url=http://www.walenz.org/vonNeumann/index.html |title=''Theory of Self-Reproducing Automata.'' |author=von Neumann, John |author2=Burks, Arthur W. |date=1966 |publisher=www.walenz.org |format=Scanned book online |accessdate=2008-02-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105213853/http://www.walenz.org/vonNeumann/index.html |archivedate=2008-01-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> This automaton was necessarily very complex due to its computation- and construction-universality. In 1968 [[Edgar F. Codd]] reduced the number of states from 29 in [[von Neumann cellular automaton|von Neumann's CA]] to 8 in [[Codd's cellular automaton|his]].<ref name=Codd68>{{cite book|author = Codd, Edgar F.|title=Cellular Automata|publisher=Academic Press, New York|year=1968}}</ref> When Christopher Langton did away with the universality condition, he was able to significantly reduce the automaton's complexity. Its self-replicating loops are based on one of the simplest elements in Codd's automaton, the periodic emitter.
== Specification ==
Langton's Loops run in a CA that has 8 states, and uses the [[von Neumann neighborhood]] with rotational symmetry. The [[State transition table|transition table]] can be found here: [http://code.google.com/p/ruletablerepository/wiki/TheRules#Self-replicating_loops].
As with [[Codd's cellular automaton|Codd's CA]], Langton's Loops consist of sheathed wires. The signals travel passively along the wires until they reach the open ends, when the command they carry is executed.
[[Image:Langtons Loop Colony.png|thumb|right|A colony of loops. The ones in the centre are "dead".]]
=== Colonies ===
Because of a particular property of the loops' "pseudopodia", they are unable to reproduce into the space occupied by another loop. Thus, once a loop is surrounded, it is incapable of reproducing, resulting in a [[coral]]-like colony with a thin layer of reproducing organisms surrounding a core of inactive "dead" organisms. Unless provided unbounded space, the colony's size will be limited. The maximum population will be [[asymptote|asymptotic]] to <math>\textstyle \left \lfloor \frac{A}{121} \right \rfloor</math>, where ''A'' is the total area of the space in cells.
=== Encoding of the genome ===
The loops' genetic code is stored as a series of nonzero-zero state pairs. The standard loop's genome is illustrated in the picture at the top, and may be stated as a series of numbered states starting from the T-junction and running clockwise: 70-70-70-70-70-70-40-40. The '70' command advances the end of the wire by one cell, while the '40-40' sequence causes the left turn. State 3 is used as a temporary marker for several stages.
While the roles of states 0,1,2,3,4 and 7 are similar to Codd's CA, the remaining states 5 and 6 are used instead to mediate the loop replication process. After the loop has completed, state 5 travels counter-clockwise along the sheath of the parent loop to the next corner, causing the next arm to be produced in a different direction. State 6 temporarily joins the genome of the daughter loop and initialises the growing arm at the next corner it reaches.
The genome is used a total of six times: once to extend the pseudopod to the desired location, four times to complete the loop, and again to [[DNA replication|transfer]] the genome into the daughter loop. Clearly, this is dependent on the fourfold [[rotational symmetry]] of the loop; without it, the loop would be incapable of containing the information required to describe it. The same use of symmetry for genome compression is used in many biological [[viruses]], such as the [[icosahedral symmetry|icosahedral]] [[adenovirus]].

This increases diversity in the evolution of new species of loops. || 10 || [[von Neumann neighborhood|von Neumann]] || 149 || 363 ||[[Image:SL_thumb.png|none|107x106px]] |}

'''Meat-free days''' are declared to discourage or prohibit the consumption of meat on certain days of the week. [[Meatless Monday|Mondays]] and [[Friday Fast|Fridays]] are the most popular days. There are also movements encouraging people giving up meat on a weekly, monthly, or permanent basis.{{cn|date=September 2018}}
== History == {{Further|Friday Fast}} Abstention from meat was historically done for religious reasons (e.g. the [[Friday Fast]]). In the [[Methodist Church]], during [[Lent]] "abstinence from meat one day a week is a universal act of penitence".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archives.umc.org/interior.asp?ptid=1&mid=2872 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100310224612/http://archives.umc.org/interior.asp?ptid=1&mid=2872 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 March 2010 |title=What does The United Methodist Church say about fasting? |publisher=The United Methodist Church |accessdate=27 April 2014 }}</ref> [[Anglican]]s (Episcopalians) and [[Roman Catholic]]s also traditionally observe Friday as a meat-free day.<ref name="Buchanan2009">{{cite book|last=Buchanan|first=Colin|title=The A to Z of Anglicanism|date=4 August 2009|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810870086|page=182|quote=In the 1662 Book of Common Prayer, there is a list of "Days of Fasting, or Abstinence," consisting of the 40 days of Lent, the ember days, the three rogation days (the Monday to Wednesday following the Sunday after Ascension Day), and all Fridays in the year (except Christmas, if it falls on a Friday).}}</ref><ref name="Green2006">{{cite book|last=Green|first=Jennifer|title=Dealing with Death: A Handbook of Practices, Procedures and Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jH2DrcY2DXMC&pg=PA224|accessdate=27 April 2014|date=25 May 2006|publisher=Jessica Kingsley Publishers|isbn=9781846425127|page=224|quote=Friday is a day of abstinence and self-denial for Catholics in health, and, by tradition, this became a meat-free day.}}</ref> Historically, Anglican and Catholic countries enforced prohibitions on eating meat on certain days of Lent. In England, for example, "butchers and victuallers were bound by heavy recognizances not to slaughter or sell meat on the weekly 'fish days', Friday and Saturday."<ref name="BarrowsRoom1991">{{cite book|last1=Barrows|first1=Susanna|last2=Room|first2=Robin|title=Drinking: Behavior and Belief in Modern History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o-wmSdtGer0C&pg=PA340|accessdate=27 April 2014|year=1991|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520070851|page=340|quote=The main legally enforced prohibition in both Catholic and Anglican countries was that against meat. During Lent, the most prominent annual season of fasting in Catholic and Anglican churches, authorities enjoined abstinence from meat and sometimes "white meats" (cheese, milk, and eggs); in sixteenth- and seventeenth-century England butchers and victuallers were bound by heavy recognizances not to slaughter or sell meat on the weekly "fish days," Friday and Saturday.}}</ref> In the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], Wednesdays and Fridays are meat-free days.<ref name="Vitz1991">{{cite book|last=Vitz|first=Evelyn Birge|title=A Continual Feast|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hrdUYzuAO14C&pg=PA80|accessdate=27 April 2014|year=1991|publisher=Ignatius Press|isbn=9780898703849|page=80|quote=In the Orthodox groups, on ordinary Wednesdays and Fridays no meat, olive oil, wine, or fish can be consumed.}}</ref> In the [[Lutheran Church]], Fridays and Saturdays are historically considered meat-free days.<ref name="Lund2002">{{cite book|last=Lund|first=Eric|title=Documents from the History of Lutheranism, 1517–1750|quote=Of the Eating of Meat: One should abstain from the eating of meat on Fridays and Saturdays, also in fasts, and this should be observed as an external ordinance at the command of his Imperial Majesty.|date=January 2002|publisher=Fortress Press|isbn=9781451407747|page=166}}</ref>
Meat-free days have also been observed due to wartime rationing (e.g. Meatless Tuesdays in Canada<ref>[http://www.city.waterloo.on.ca/VeteransGreen/PrinterFriendly.aspx?tabid=1381 "Making Do with Less": Rationing in Canada] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121216045606/http://www.city.waterloo.on.ca/VeteransGreen/PrinterFriendly.aspx?tabid=1381 |date=2012-12-16 }}</ref> and the United States—which also observed Wheatless Wednesdays—during [[World War I]])<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/food/the-history-kitchen/history-meatless-mondays/ |title=History of Meatless Mondays | The History Kitchen | PBS Food |publisher=Pbs.org |date= |accessdate=2015-11-02}}</ref><ref>[http://dinersjournal.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/23/the-way-we-ate-the-year-harry-truman-passed-on-pumpkin-pie/ The Way We Ate: The Year Harry Truman Passed on Pumpkin Pie]</ref> or in states with [[shortage economy|failing economies]].
In the [[People's Republic of Poland]], meat-free days were encouraged by the government due to [[Market (economics)|market]] forces. They were aimed at limiting meat consumption, primarily in favour of [[flour]]-based foods. The meat-free day was traditionally Friday, Monday or Wednesday.
== Ecology and society == Attempts to reintroduce meat-free days are part of a campaign to reduce [[Global warming|anthropogenic climate change]] and improve human health and [[animal welfare]] by reducing [[factory farming]] and promoting [[vegetarianism]] or [[veganism]].

{{Infobox person | name = Melville Davisson Post | image = File:Melville Post.JPG | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by the blind and visually impaired's speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = About 1919 | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1869|04|19}} | birth_place = Harrison County, West Virginia, US | death_date = {{Death date and age|1930|06|23|1869|04|19}} | death_place = Harrison County, West Virginia | death_cause = Fall Accident | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Author, lawyer | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Melville Davisson Post''' (April 19, 1869 – June 23, 1930) was an American author, born in [[Harrison County, West Virginia]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Oxford Companion to Crime and Mystery Writing|author=Herbert, Rosemary |publisher=Oxford University Press|date= 2000}}</ref> Although his name is not immediately familiar to those outside of specialist circles, many of his collections are still in print, and many collections of detective fiction include works by him. Post's best-known character is the mystery solving, justice dispensing [[West Virginia]]n backwoodsman, [[#Uncle Abner|Uncle Abner]].<ref name="Bottum">{{cite web |title=America's Greatest Mystery Writer |url=http://www.firstthings.com/onthesquare/2007/05/americas-greatest-mystery-writ |first=Joseph |last=Bottum|authorlink=Joseph Bottum (author)|date=May 1, 2007 |accessdate=November 13, 2013 |publisher=''[[First Things]]'' |website=FirstThings.com}}</ref> The 22 Uncle Abner tales, written between 1911 and 1928, have been called some of "the finest mysteries ever written".<ref name="Bottum"/>
Post's other recurring characters include the lawyers Randolph Mason and Colonel Braxton, and the detectives Sir Henry Marquis and Monsieur Jonquelle.<ref name=nevins>{{cite book|last1=Nevins|first1=Francis M.|title=Judges & Justice & Lawyers & Law: Exploring the Legal Dimensions of Fiction and Film|date=2014|publisher=Perfect Crime Books|isbn=9781935797692|pages=12–60|chapter=From Darwinian to Biblical Lawyering: Melville Davisson Post}}</ref> His total output was approximately 230 titles, including several non-crime novels.<ref name=moore>{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Charles F.|title=Melville Davisson Post|url=http://www.wvencyclopedia.org/articles/1902|website=e-WV: The West Virginia Encyclopedia|accessdate=5 January 2016|date=8 December 2015}}</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life and education=== Post was born on 19 April 1869 in Harrison County, West Virginia, the son of Ira Carper Post, a wealthy farmer; his mother was Florence May (née Davisson).<ref name=powell>{{cite book|last1=Routledge|first1=Christopher|editor1-last=Powell|editor1-first=Stephen|title=100 American Crime Writers|date=2012|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9781137031662|pages=281–282|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lhfxt0UVz8cC&pg=PA281|chapter=Post, Melville Davisson (1869-1930)|accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref> Post's family had settled in the [[Clarksburg, West Virginia]] area in the late 18th century, and <ref name=moore /> Post earned a law degree from [[West Virginia University]] in 1892.
===Personal life=== In 1903, he married Ann Bloomfield Gamble Schofield. Their only child (a son, Ira) died in infancy, after which Melville and Ann travelled in Europe. They later owned and managed a stable for [[Polo pony|polo ponies]].<ref name=powell /> Ann died of pneumonia in 1919.
===Death=== Post, an avid horseman, died on June 23, 1930, after a fall crash from his horse, and was buried in Harrison County.<ref>Sullivan, Ken (ed.), ''The West Virginia Encyclopedia'', West Virginia Humanities Council, 2006. pg. 578</ref>
==Legacy== Post's boyhood home, "[[Templemoor]]", was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1982.<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref>
==Fiction==
===Randolph Mason===
Post wrote three volumes of stories about Randolph Mason, a brusque New York lawyer who is highly skilled at turning legal [[loopholes]] and [[legal technicality|technicalities]] to his clients' advantage.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mallory|first1=Michael|title='The Man of Last Resort': the Outrageous World of Randolph Mason|journal=Mystery Scene|date=2005|volume=Fall|issue=91|url=https://www.mysteryscenemag.com/blog-article/2858-qthe-man-of-last-resortq-the-outrageous-world-of-randolph-mason|accessdate=29 March 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304122009/https://www.mysteryscenemag.com/blog-article/2858-qthe-man-of-last-resortq-the-outrageous-world-of-randolph-mason|archivedate=4 March 2016}}</ref>
In the first two volumes (''The Strange Schemes of Randolph Mason'' and ''The Man of Last Resort'', published 1896–1897), Mason is depicted as an utterly amoral character who advises criminals how to commit wrongdoings without breaking the [[letter of the law]]. The best-known of these stories is "The Corpus Delicti", in which Mason's client murders a [[blackmail]]ing lover and dissolves her dismembered corpse in acid. Despite overwhelming [[circumstantial evidence]], Mason secures his client's acquittal on the grounds that no body has been found and there are no eyewitnesses to the woman's death. (New York law at the time allowed one of the two conditions to be established by circumstantial evidence, but not both.)<ref name=loerzel>{{cite web|last1=Loerzel|first1=Robert|title=The Corpus Delicti|url=http://www.alchemyofbones.com/stories/corpus.htm|website=Alchemy of Bones|accessdate=2 January 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926221040/http://www.alchemyofbones.com/stories/corpus.htm|archivedate=2 January 2016}}</ref> Post deflected criticism of such sensational stories by declaring that he was publicly exposing weaknesses in the law that needed to be rectified. Nevertheless, in a third volume (1908's ''The Corrector of Destinies''), Mason had become a reformed man who used his knowledge of the law for more beneficent purposes. Post explained Mason's change of character by stating the lawyer had been suffering from mental illness in the two earlier volumes.<ref name=nevins /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Patricia J.|title=The Image of the Attorney: The Character of Attorney Randolph Mason in three books by Melville Davisson Post|date=2010|url=http://works.bepress.com/patricia_brown/1|website=Selected Works|publisher=Bepress|accessdate=2 January 2016}}</ref>
=== Uncle Abner ===
Uncle Abner is Post's best-known literary creation, the character, one of six detectives created by Post,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/252700230|title=Whodunit? : a who's who in crime & mystery writing|last=Rosemary.|first=Herbert,|date=2003-01-01|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=0195157613|location=|page=3|oclc=252700230|quote=|via=}}</ref> having appeared in 22 stories that were serialized in American magazines (primarily ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]'') between 1911 and 1928. The first tale, "The Angel of the Lord", is perhaps the very first work in the [[historical mystery]] genre. Uncle Abner solved the mysteries that confronted him in a backwoods West Virginia community, immediately prior to the [[American Civil War]] and before the infant nation had any proper police system. He had two great attributes for his self-imposed task: a profound knowledge of and love for the [[Bible]], and a keen observation of human actions. One example of Uncle Abner's keen deductive skills is his showing a deaf man had not written a document, because a word in it was phonetically mis-spelt.<ref name="Bottum"/><ref name="WVE 813">{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Charles F.|title=Uncle Abner|url=http://www.wvencyclopedia.org/articles/813|website=e-WV: The West Virginia Encyclopedia|accessdate=5 January 2016|date=5 December 2010}}</ref>
[[Ellery Queen]] would later call the stories "an out-of-this-world target for future detective-story writers." In his 1924 book of literary criticism ''Cargoes for Crusoes'', Grant Overton called the publication of Post's "The Doomdorf Mystery" a "major literary event", and in ''Murder for Pleasure'' (1941), Howard Haycraft called Uncle Abner "the greatest American contribution" to the list of fictional detectives after [[Edgar Allan Poe]]'s [[C. Auguste Dupin]].<ref name="Bottum"/><ref name="WVE 813"/> After Post's death, more stories about Abner were written (at the request of the Melville Davisson Post estate) by the retired American research chemist, John F. Suter (1914-1996).
===Other characters===
Besides Mason, Abner, and Walker, Post also created the detectives Sir Henry Marquis of Scotland Yard (''The Sleuth of St James Square'', 1920), the French policeman Monsieur Jonquelle (''Monsieur Jonquelle: Prefect of Police of Paris'', 1923), and the Virginia lawyer Colonel Braxton (''The Silent Witness'', 1930).

{{other people||Michael Todd (disambiguation)}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = Michael James Todd |honorific suffix = [[Queen's Police Medal|QPM]] |image = |image_size = 160px |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1957|8|10}} |birth_place = [[Essex]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2008|3|11|1957|8|10}} |death_place = Bwlch Glas, [[Snowdon]], Wales |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = |other_names = |known_for = |education = |alma_mater = |employer = [[Greater Manchester Police]] |occupation = [[Chief Constable]] |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Michael James Todd''' [[Queen's Police Medal|QPM]] (10 August 1957 – 11 March 2008[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article3540685.ece Michael Todd: The Times obituary]. ''[[The Times]]''. London. 12 March 2008) was [[Chief Constable]] of [[Greater Manchester Police]] from October 2002 until his death. ==Biography== Todd grew up in Essex where he attended the [[Billericay School]] and later attended the [[University of Essex]].{{cite web | url = http://www.echo-news.co.uk/mostpopular.var.2111469.mostviewed.update_tributes_to_chief_constable.php | accessdate = 16 March 2008 |title=UPDATE: Tributes to Chief Constable}} He graduated with a [[first class honours]] degree in government in 1989 and a master's degree in [[political science|politics]] in 1994.{{cite news |title=Profile: Mike Todd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7290524.stm |work=BBC News |publisher= |date=11 March 2008 |accessdate=11 March 2008 }}{{cite news |first=John |last=Fahey |title=Michael Todd: profile |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/michael-todd-profile-794271.html |work=The Independent |publisher= |date=11 March 2008 |accessdate=11 March 2008 }} The university named him the alumnus of the year in 2003 for his contributions to policing and the community.{{cite web|title=University of Essex Alumni Website|url=http://www.essex.ac.uk/alumni/|accessdate=15 March 2008}} He joined [[Essex Police]] in 1976, and the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] on a management exchange programme. Todd was appointed an Assistant Chief Constable in Nottinghamshire in 1995, initially managing support services and then operational policing. In 1998, he was appointed as the Deputy Assistant Commissioner back in the Metropolitan Police. In 2000, following his promotion to Assistant Commissioner in the Metropolitan Police, he was responsible for Territorial Policing, covering all 32 London Boroughs. In 2002, he was selected as Chief Constable of Greater Manchester Police from 2002 and in 2006 he became a vice-president of ACPO ([[Association of Chief Police Officers]]), both posts he held until his death.{{cite news |first=John |last=Fahey |title=Michael Todd: profile |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/michael-todd-profile-794271.html |work=The Independent |publisher= |date=11 March 2008 |accessdate=22 January 2013 }} ===Investigation of CIA extraordinary rendition flights=== Todd investigated on behalf of the Association of Chief Police Officers the [[extraordinary rendition]] flights conducted by the [[CIA]] to transport [[detainee]]s.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/06/09/nflight109.xml |title= Police deny 'extraordinary rendition' flights |publisher=Telegraph |date=10 June 2007 |accessdate=12 March 2008}} ===Taser demonstration=== Todd allowed himself to be hit by a [[taser]] in 2005 to demonstrate that the [[Electroshock weapon|stun guns]] were safe; this was an effort to have them more widely issued to police officers. "I couldn't move, it hurt like hell," he said after recovering. "I wouldn't want to do that again."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/manchester/4650645.stm Chief constable hit by Taser gun]. [[BBC News]]. 5 July 2005. ===Investigation into malpractice=== In 2012, it was announced that Police officials are examining new claims of financial malpractice against Todd. Greater Manchester's new Police Commissioner appealed for information about Michael Todd, former chief constable of the force. The claims centre on Todd's role in drawing up unique contracts that allowed some staff to get enormous payoffs when they left the force. Tony Lloyd, a former Labour Foreign Office minister who has just been elected Police Commissioner for the force, is to be handed a report into allegations of possible financial malpractice, including 'golden goodbye' redundancy packages of up to £300,000. ==Personal life== He was married with three children, a daughter and twin boys. His social interests included Warhammer (Space Marines), computer gaming and reading, particularly military and political biographies. ===Death=== After Todd was reported missing by Greater Manchester Police, rescue teams from [[Llanberis]], [[North Wales]], started a search for him at 01:00 on 11 March 2008. After being alerted by hill walkers who found personal possessions, they found Todd's body in the ''Bwlch Glas'' area of [[Snowdon]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7290359.stm |title=Top UK police chief is found dead |publisher=BBC |date=11 March 2008 |accessdate=10 March 2008}} The [[Autopsy|post-mortem]] report initially found "no obvious cause" of death.{{cite web | url = http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,30100-1308956,00.html | work = Sky News | title = No 'Obvious Cause' Of Top Cop's Death | accessdate = 12 March 2008}} After his death, [[Manchester]] [[Chamber of Commerce]] Chief Executive Angie Robinson was reported to have been having an affair with Todd. It was later revealed that he was conducting numerous affairs with up to 38 different women. Todd's widow Carolyn paid tribute to "a caring and loving father and husband."{{cite news | first= | last= | author2= | title=Todd inquest hears of drink level | date=13 March 2008 | publisher= | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/manchester/7294994.stm | work =BBC News | pages = | accessdate = 24 October 2008 | language = }} The [[inquest]] into his death was opened and adjourned on 13 March 2008. The inquest ruled that Todd had died from [[Hypothermia|exposure]], essentially freezing to death having been only lightly clothed on the slopes of Snowdon.{{cite news | first= | last= | author2= | title=Widow forgives dead police chief | date=6 October 2008 | publisher= | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7655611.stm | work =BBC News | pages = | accessdate = 24 October 2008 | language = }} ==Honours==

Mental illness can be a consequence of [[miscarriage]] or early pregnancy loss.<ref name="BMJ Best Practice">{{Cite web|url=http://us.bestpractice.bmj.com/best-practice/monograph/666.html|title=Miscarriage|last=BMJ Best Practice|first=|date=|website=us.bestpractice.bmj.com|language=en|others=Ida Muslim, Jothi Doraiswamy, Acknowledgements|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-08}}</ref><ref name = rand>{{Cite journal | last1 =Randolph |first1 = Amber L. | last2 = Hruby | first2 = Brittaney T.| first3 =Shaakira | last3=Sharif | title = Counseling Women Who Have Experienced Pregnancy Loss: A Review of the Literature | date = 4 April 2015 | number = 1 | volume = 14| publisher = Adult Span Journal}}</ref> Even though women can develop long-term psychiatric symptoms after a miscarriage, acknowledging the potential of mental illness is not usually considered.<ref name=Christiansen2017/> A [[Mental disorder|mental illness]] can develop in women who have experienced one or more [[miscarriage]]s after the event or even years later.{{sfn|Seftel|page = }}<ref name="BMJ Best Practice"/> Some data suggest that men and women can be affected up to 15 years after the loss.<ref name="daug" /> Though recognized as a public health problem, studies investigating the mental health status of women following miscarriage are still lacking.<ref name= daug/> [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) can develop in women who have experienced a miscarriage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.figo.org/news/what-psychological-impact-miscarriage-0015410|title=What is the psychological impact of miscarriage? {{!}} FIGO|last=International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics|first=|date=|website=|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-23}}</ref><ref name=daug>{{Cite journal|last=Daugirdaitė|first=Viltė|last2=Akker|first2=Olga van den|last3=Purewal|first3=Satvinder|date=2015|title=Posttraumatic Stress and Posttraumatic Stress Disorder after Termination of Pregnancy and Reproductive Loss: A Systematic Review|url=https://www.hindawi.com/journals/jp/2015/646345/|journal=Journal of Pregnancy|language=en|volume=2015|pages=1–14|doi=10.1155/2015/646345|pmid=25734016|pmc=4334933|issn=2090-2727}}</ref><ref name = kirs/> Risks for developing PTSD after miscarriage include [[Psychological pain|emotional pain]], expressions of emotion, and low levels of [[social support]].<ref name= daug/> Even if relatively low levels of [[Stress (biology)|stress]] occur after the miscarriage, symptoms of PTSD including [[Flashback (psychology)|flashbacks]], [[intrusive thought]]s, [[Dissociation (psychology)|dissociation]] and [[Fight-or-flight response|hyperarousal]] can later develop.{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} [[Clinical depression]] also is associated with miscarriage.<ref name = sche/> Past responses by clinicians have been to prescribe sedatives.<ref>{{cite book | last = Quagliata | first = Emanuela | title = Becoming Parents and Overcoming Obstacles : Understanding the Experience of Miscarriage, Premature Births, Infertility, and Postnatal Depression | publisher = Karnac Books | location = City | year = 2013 | isbn = 9781782200185 }}</ref>
Recurring miscarriage may increase the incidence of intrusive thoughts in women and their partners.<ref name="daug" />
Miscarriage has an emotional effect and can also lead to [[psychological disorders]]. One disorder that can develop is primary maternal preoccupation. This [[psychological trauma]] can develop as a response to early pregnancy loss. [[Anxiety]] can also develop as a result of a miscarriage.<ref name=sche>{{Cite journal|last=Scheidt|first=CE|date=2007|title=Trauerverarbeitung nach Prä- und Perinatalverlust (Mourning processing after pre-and perinatal loss)|journal=Psychother Psych Med|volume=57|issue=1|pages=4–11|doi=10.1055/s-2006-951906|pmid=17357028}}</ref> Women describe the medical treatment that they receive contributed their distress.<ref name= daug/> Even if relatively low levels of [[Stress (biology)|stress]] occur after the miscarriage, symptoms of PTSD including [[Flashback (psychology)|flashbacks]], [[Dissociation (psychology)|dissociation]] and [[Fight-or-flight response|hyperarousal]] can later develop.{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} [[Clinical depression]] also is associated with miscarriage.<ref name = sche/>
Intrusive thoughts can develop after the loss.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>{{sfn|Seftel|page=60}} Panic disorder and obsessive thoughts may also develop as a response to a miscarriage.<ref name=":0" /> Men may experience pain and psychological effects but react by adopting “compensatory behaviours” such as increasing consumption of alcohol. Because men can consider their role to be supportive, they may not have their loss recognized.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Due|first=Clemence|last2=Chiarolli|first2=Stephanie|last3=Riggs|first3=Damien W.|date=2017-11-15|title=The impact of pregnancy loss on men's health and wellbeing: a systematic review|journal=BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth|volume=17|issue=1|pages=380|doi=10.1186/s12884-017-1560-9|pmid=29141591|pmc=5688642|issn=1471-2393}}</ref>
==Posttraumatic stress disorder== Women who have had clinical depression before the miscarriage are more likely to develop PTSD.<ref name=Christiansen2017/> [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]] is associated with miscarriage along with other traumatic events associated with pregnancy.<ref name=Christiansen2017>{{cite journal|last1=Christiansen|first1=DM|title=Posttraumatic stress disorder in parents following infant death: A systematic review|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|date=February 2017|volume=51|pages=60–74|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2016.10.007|pmid=27838460}}</ref>{{sfn|Martin|page = 26 }}<ref name = kirs>{{Cite journal|last=Kersting|first=Anette|last2=Wagner|first2=Birgit|date=June 2012|title=Complicated grief after perinatal loss|url=|journal=Dialogues in Clinical Neuroscience|volume=14|issue=2|pages=187–194|pmc=3384447|pmid=22754291}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Daugirdaitė|first1=V|last2=van den Akker|first2=O|last3=Purewal|first3=S|title=Posttraumatic stress and posttraumatic stress disorder after termination of pregnancy and reproductive loss: a systematic review|journal=Journal of Pregnancy|date=2015|volume=2015|pages=1-14|doi=10.1155/2015/646345|pmid=25734016|pmc=4334933}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Those who experience recurrent miscarriage (>3) have a greater risk of developing PTSD than those who have experienced miscarriage once.<ref name=Christiansen2017/> An association between the gender of the infant lost through miscarriage exists whereby there is an increased chance of developing PTSD if the infant was a male. Knowing the cause of the miscarriage does not reduce the risk of developing PTSD. Finding a 'meaning' for the loss reduces the risk of developing PTSD. A negative outlook regarding the world in general is corrlated with increased levels of PTSD. Poor self-esteem is also related to developing PTSD after the loss. If memories of the loss are considered intense, risk for PTSD is increased. There are concerns that PTSD in mothers may have a negative impact on children born after the event.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
Though the development of PTSD in women and families after the loss has been identified, the presence of PTSD in a woman who is pregnant is detrimental. Women with PTSD are thought to be at a higher risk of prenatal loss, perinatal loss, pregnancy complications, ectopic pregnancy, preterm birth and growth abnormalities in the fetus.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
PTSD in a mother is suspected to increase the risk of autism, hypertension, cardiovascular diseases, and type 2 diabetes in a child.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
==Depression and anxiety== 43% of women who miscarry are found to have depression, anxiety disorders, and obsessive-compulsive disorder.<ref name = rand/><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/880941778|title=Women's reproductive mental health across the lifespan|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Lynn-Barnes, Diana,|isbn=9783319051161|location=Cham|pages=|oclc=880941778 |postscript = (online text, no page numbers)|last1=Barnes|first1=Diana Lynn|date=2014-05-30}}</ref> <!--and [[bipolar disorder]].{{mcn|date=October 2017}} [[ Impact of Event Scale - Revised (IES-R)]] has been used to quantify the severity of a miscarriage and 47.5% of the women experiencing a miscarriage have high scores. Follow-up determined that even after 2 years, 2.6% of women still have high impact scores.{{mcn|date=October 2017}}-->
[[Prolonged grief disorder|Complicated grief]] is an [[Atypical depression|atypical]] response to a miscarriage. It differs from the more common form of [[Miscarriage and grief|grief]] that occurs after a miscarriage. The [[Kübler-Ross model|grieving process]] associated with other events such as the loss of a spouse or parent is expected to decline in a predictable and steady rate. This not true for those experiencing grief after a miscarriage because only 41% follow the expected decline in grief while most (59%) do not fit this pattern.<ref name = kirs/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/2012/06/miscarriage.aspx|title=Miscarriage and loss|publisher = American Psychological Association | date = 2017 |language=en|access-date=2017-09-23}}</ref>
[[Cognitive behavioral therapy|Cognitive Behavior Therapy]] has been found to be helpful if it is begun immediately after the loss.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
== Epidemeology == A woman who miscarries has a 2.5 times greater risk for depression than those who have not.<ref name=":0" /> In the US, estimates of PTSD related to miscarriage are thought to be 150,000–200,000 acute and 24,000–32,000 chronic PTSD cases. PTSD in fathers may be significant but remains unaddressed.<ref name=Christiansen2017/>
== References == {{reflist}}

Art by [[Gary Frank]], [[Cam Smith]] and [[Glynis Wein|Glynis Oliver]] |real_name=Harley Davis |species=Human [[Cyborg]] |publisher=[[Marvel UK]] |debut=''Motormouth 1'' (June [[1992 in comics|1992]]) |creators=Graham Marks
[[Gary Frank]] |alliances=[[MI-13 (comics)|MI-13]] |partners=[[Killpower]] |aliases= |powers=-Sonic scream
